div.p: THE WHITE DIVEL, OR, The Tragedy of Paulo Giordano Ursini, Duke of Brachiano, With The Life and Death of Vittoria Corombona the famous Venetian Curtizan.
Acted by the Queenes Maiesties Seruants.
LONDON, Printed by N. O. for Thomas Archer, and are to be sold at his Shop in Popes head Pallace, neere the Royall Exchange. 1612.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IN publishing this Tragedy, I do but challenge to my selfe that liberty, which other men haue tane before mee; not that I affect praise by it, for, nos haec nouimus esse nihil, onely since it was acted, in so dull a time of Winter, presented in so open and blacke a Theater, that it wanted (that which is the onely grace and setting out of a Tragedy) a full and vnderstanding Auditory: and that since that time I haue noted, most of the people that come to that Play-house, resemble those ignorant asses (who visiting Stationers shoppes their vse is not to inquire for good bookes, but new bookes) I present it to the generall view with this confidence.
Nec Rhoncos metues, maligniorum,
Nec Scombris tunicas, dabis molestas.

If it be obiected this is no true Drammaticke Poem, I shall easily confesse it, non potes in nugas dicere plura meas: Ipse ego quam dixi, willingly, and not ignorantly, in this kind haue I faulted: for should a man present to such an Auditory, the most sententious Tragedy that euer was written, obseruing all the critticall lawes, as height of stile; and grauety of person; inrich it with the sententious Chorus, and as it
were life'n Death, in the passionate and waighty Nuntius: yet after all this diuine rapture, O dura messorum ilia, the breath that comes from the vncapable multitude, is able to poison it, and ere it be acted, let the Author resolue to fix to euery scoene, this of Horace,
— Haec hodie Porcis comedenda relinques.

To those who report I was a long time in finishing this Tragedy, I confesse I do not write with a goose-quill, winged with two feathers, and if they will needes make it my fault, I must answere them with that of Eurypides to Alcestides, a Tragicke Writer: Alcestides obiecting that Eurypides had onely in three daies composed three verses, whereas himselfe had written three hundreth: Thou telst truth, (quoth he) but heres the difference, thine shall onely bee read for three daies, whereas mine shall continue three ages.

Detraction is the sworne friend to ignorance: For mine owne part I haue euer truly cherisht my good opinion of other mens worthy Labours, especially of that full and haightned stile of Maister Chapman. The labor'd and vnderstanding workes of Maister Iohnson: The no lesse worthy composures of the both worthily excellent Maister Beamont, & Maister Fletcher: And lastly (without wrong last to be named) the right happy and copious industry of M. Shake-speare, M. Decker, & M. Heywood, wishing what I write may be read by their light: Protesting, that, in the strength of mine owne iudgement, I know them so worthy, that though I rest silent in my owne worke, yet to most of theirs I dare (without flattery) fix that of Martiall.

div.head: THE TRAGEDY OF PAVLO GIORDANO Vrsini Duke of Brachiano, and Vittoria Corombona.

sp.stage: Enter Count Lodouico, Antonelli and Gasparo.

sp.speaker: LODOVICO.
sp.l: BAnisht?

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: It greeu'd me much to heare the sentence.

sp.speaker: LODO.
sp.l: Ha, Ha, ô Democritus thy Gods
That gouerne the whole world! Courtly reward, and punishment. Fortun's a right whore.
If she giue ought, she deales it in smal percels,
That she may take away all at one swope.
This tis to haue great enemies, God quite them:
Your woolfe no longer seemes to be a woolfe
Then when shees hungry.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: You terme those enemies
Are men of Princely ranke.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Oh I pray for them.
The violent thunder is adored by those
Are pasht in peeces by it.

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: Come my Lord,
You are iustly dom'd, looke but a little backe
Into your former life: you haue in three yeares
Ruin'd the noblest Earldome

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Your followers
Haue swallowed you like Mummia, and being sicke
With such vnnaturall and horrid Phisicke
Vomit you vp ith kennell

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: All the damnable degrees
Of drinkings haue you, you staggerd through one Cittizen.
Is Lord of two faire Manors, cald you master
Only for Cauiare.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Those noblemen
Which were inuited to your prodigall feastes,
Wherin the Phaenix scarce could scape your throtes,
Laugh at your misery, as fore-deeminge you:
An idle Meteor which drawne forth the earth
Would bee soone lost ith aire.

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: Ieast vpon you,
And say you were begotten in an Earthquake,
You haue ruin'd such faire Lordships.

sp.speaker: LODO.
sp.l: Very good,
This Well goes with two buckets, I must tend
The powring out of eather.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Worse then these,
You haue acted, certaine Murders here in Rome,
Bloody and full of horror.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Las they were flea-bytinges?
Why tooke they not my head then?

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: O my Lord
The law doth somtimes mediate, thinkes it good
Not euer to steepe violent sinnes in blood,
This gentle pennance may both end your crimes,
And in the example better these bad times.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: So, but I wonder then some great men scape
This banishment, ther's Paulo Giordano Orfani,
The Duke of Brachiano, now liues in Rome,
And by close pandarisme seekes to prostitute
The honour of Uittoria Corombona,
Vittoria, she that might haue got my pardon
For one kisse to the Duke.

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: Haue a full man within you,
Wee see that Trees beare no such pleasant fruite
There where they grew first, as where the are new set.
Perfumes the more they are chaf'd the more they render
Their pleasing sents, and so affliction
Expresseth vertue, fully, whether trew,
Or ells adulterate.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Leaue your painted comforts,
Ile make Italian cut-works in their guts
If euer I returne.

sp.speaker: GASP.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: LODO.
sp.l: I am patient,
I haue seene some ready to be executed
Giue pleasant lookes, and money, and growne familiar
With the knaue hangman, so do I, I thanke them,
And would account them nobly mercifull
Would they dispatch me quicklie,

sp.speaker: ANTO.
sp.l: Fare you well,
Wee shall find time I doubt not to repeale
Your banishment.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I am euer bound to you:
This is the worlds almes; pray make vse of it,
Great men sell sheep, thus to be cut in peeces,
When first they haue shorne them bare and sold their fleeces.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, Camillo, Flamineo, Uittoria Corombona.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Your best of rest.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Vnto my Lord the Duke,
The best of well come, More lights, attend the Duke.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Flamineo.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Quite lost Flamineo.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Pursew your noble wishes, I am prompt
As lightning to your seruice, ô my Lord!
The faire Vittoria, my happy sister
Shall giue you present audience, gentlemen
Let the caroach go on, and tis his pleasure
You put out all your torches and depart.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Are wee so happy.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Can't be otherwise?
Obseru'd you not to night my honor'd Lord
Which way so ere you went shee threw her eyes,
I haue dealt already with her chamber-maid
Zanche the More, and she is wondrous proud
To be the agent for so high a spirit.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Wee are happie aboue thought, because boue merrit.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: 'boue merrit! wee may now talke freely :'boue merrit; what ist you doubt, her coynesse, thats but the superficies of lust most women haue; yet why should Ladyes blush to heare that nam'd, which they do not feare to handle? O they are polliticke, They know our desire is increas'd by the difficultie of injoying; where a satiety is a blunt, weary and drowsie passion, if the buttery hatch at Court stood continually open their would be nothing so passionat crouding, nor hot suit after the beuerage,

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: O but her iealous husband.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p:
Hang him, a guilder that hath his braynes perisht with
quicke-siluer is not more could in the liuer. The great Barriers moulted not more feathers then he hath shed haires, by the confession of his doctor. An Irish gamster that will play himselfe naked, and then wage all downeward, at hazard, is not more venterous. So vn-able to please a woman that like a dutch doublet all his backe is shrunke into his breeches.
Shrowd you within this closet, good my Lord,
Some tricke now must be thought on to deuide
My brother in law from his faire bed-fellow,

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: O should she faile to come,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I must not haue your Lordship thus vnwisely amorous,
sp.p: I my selfe haue loued a lady and peursued her with a great deale of vnder-age protestation, whom some 3. or 4. gallants that haue enioyed would with all their harts haue bin glad to haue bin rid of Tis iust like a summer bird-cage in a garden, the birds that are without, despaire to get in, and the birds that are within despaire and are in a consumption for feare they shall neuer get out: away away my Lord,
sp.l: See here he comes, this fellow by his apparell
Some men would iudge a pollititian,
But call his wit in question you shall find it
Merely an Asse in's foot cloath,
How now brother what trauailing to bed to your kind wife?

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: I assure you brother no, My voyage lyes
More northerlie, in a farre colder clime,
I do not well remember I protest when I last lay with her.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Strange you should loose your Count.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Wee neuer lay together but eare morning
Their grew a flaw betweene vs.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: T'had byn your part
To haue made vp that flaw.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Trew, but shee loathes I should be seene in't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Why Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: The Duke your maister visits me I thanke him,
And I perceaue how like an earnest bowler
Hee very passionatelie leanes that way,
He should haue his boule runne

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I hope you do not thinke

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: That noble men boule bootie, Faith his cheeke
Hath a most excellent Bias, it would faine iumpe with my mistris.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Will you be an asse.
Despight you Aristotle or a Cocould
Contrary to your Ephemerides
Which shewes you vnder what a smiling planet
You were first swadled,

sp.speaker: CAM:
sp.l: Pew wew, Sir tell not me
Of planets nor of Ephemeridas
A man may be made Cocould in the day time
When the Stars eyes are out.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Sir God boy you,
I do commit you to your pittifull pillow
Stuft with horne-shauings.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: God refuse me
Might I aduise you now your onlie course
Weare to locke vp your wife.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: T'weare very good.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Bar her the sight of reuels.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Let her not go to Church, but like a hounde
In Leon at your heeles.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Tweare for her honour

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And so you should be certayne in one fortnight,
Despight her chastity or innocence
To bee Cocoulded, which yet is in suspence:
This is my counsell and I aske no see for't.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Come you know not where my night cap wringes mee.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Weare it ath' old fashion, let your large eares come through, it will be more easy, nay I will be bitter, barre your wife of her entertaynment: women are more willinglie & more gloriouslie chast, when they are least restrayned of their libertie. It seemes you would be a fine Capricious Mathematically iealous Coxcombe, take the height of your owne hornes with a Iacobs staffe afore they are vp. These polliticke inclosures for paltry mutton, makes more rebellion in the flesh then all the prouocatiue electuaries Doctors haue vttered sence last Iubilee.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: This doth not phisicke me,

sp.speaker: FLA:
sp.p:
It seemes you are Iealous, ile shew you the error of it by a familiar example, I haue seene a paire of spectacles fashiond with such perspectiue art, that lay downe but one twelue pence ath' bord twill appeare as if there were twenty, now should you
weare a paire of these spectacles, and see your wife tying her shooe, you would Imagine twenty hands were taking vp of your wiues clothes, and this would put you into a horrible causlesse fury,

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: The fault there Sir is not in the eye-sight

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: True, but they that haue the yellow Iaundeise, thinke all obiects they looke on to bee yellow. Iealousy is worser, her fit's present to a man, like so many bubles in a Bason of water, twenty seuerall crabbed faces, many times makes his owne shadow his cocould-maker.* See she comes, what reason Enter Corombona. haue you to be iealous of this creature? what an ignorant asse or flattering knaue might he be counted, that should write sonnets to her eyes, or call her brow the snow of Ida, or Iuorie of Corinth, or compare her haire to the blacke birds bill, when 'tis liker the blacke birds feather. This is all: Be wise, I will make you freinds and you shall go to bed together, marry looke you, it shall not be your seeking, do you stand vpon that by any meanes, walk you a loofe, I would not haue you seene in't, sister my Lord attends you in the banquetting house, your husband is wondrous discontented.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.p: I did nothing to displease him, I carued to him at supper-time

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: You need not haue carued him infaith, they say he is a capon already, I must now seemingly fall out with you. Shall a gentleman so well descended as Camillo.— a lousy slaue that within this twenty yeares rode with the blacke guard in the Dukes cariage mongst spits and dripping-pannes.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Now he begins to tickle her.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: An excellent scholler, one that hath a head fild with calues braynes without any sage in them,— come crouching in the hams to you for a nights lodging— that hath an itch in's hams, which like the fier at the glasse house hath not gone out this seauen yeares— is hee not a courtly gentleman,— when he weares white sattin one would take him by his blacke mussel to be no other creature then a maggot, you are a goodly Foile, I confesse, well set out— but couerd with a false stone you conterfaite dyamond.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: He will make her know what is in mee.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Come, my Lord attends you, thou shalt go to bed to my Lord.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Now he comes to't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: With a relish as curious as a vintner going to taste new wine, I am opening your case hard.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: A vertuous brother a my credit.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: He will giue thee a ringe with a philosophers stone in it.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Indeede I am studying Alcumye.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Thou shalt lye in a bed stuft with turtles feathers, swoone in perfumed lynnen like the fellow was smothered in roses, so perfect shall be thy happinesse, that as men at Sea thinke land and trees and shippes go that way they go, so both heauen and earth shall seeme to go your voyage. Shal't meete him, tis fixt, with nayles of dyamonds to ineuitable necessitie.

sp.speaker: VITTO.
sp.l: How shals rid him hence?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I will put brees in's tayle, set him gadding presentlie, I haue almost wrought her to it, I find her comming, but might I aduise you now for this night I would not lye with her, I would crosse her humor to make her more humble.

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.l: Shall I, shall I?

sp.speaker: FLA:
sp.l: It will shew in you a supremacie of Iudgement.

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.p: Trew, and a mind differing from the tumultuary opinion, for quae negata grat.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Right you are the Adamant shall draw her to you, though you keepe distance of:

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.l: A philosophicall reason.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Walke by her a'the noble mans fashion, and tell her you will lye with her at the end of the Progresse

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.p: Vittoria, I cannot be induc'd, or as a man would say incited.

sp.speaker: VITTO.
sp.l: To do what Sir?

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.p: To lye with you to night; your silkeworme vseth to fast euery third day, and the next following spinnes the better. Tomorrow at night I am for you.

sp.speaker: VITTO.
sp.l: Youle spinne a faire thread, trust to't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: But do you heare I shall haue you steale to her chamber about midnight.

sp.speaker: CAMIL.
sp.p:
Do you thinke so, why looke you brother, because
you shall not thinke ile gull you, take the key, locke me into the chamber, and say you shall be sure of me.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Introth I will, ile be your iaylor once,
But haue you nere a false dore.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.p: A pox on't, as I am a Christian tell mee to morrow how scuruelie shee takes my vnkind parting

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.p: Didst thou not make the ieast of the silke-worme? good night in faith I will vse this tricke often,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Do, do, do.
sp.p: So now you are safe. Ha ha ha, thou intanglest thy selfe in thine owne worke like a silke-worme

Come sister, darkenesse hides your blush, women are like curst dogges, ciuilitie keepes them tyed all day time, but they are let loose at midnight, then they do most good or most mischeefe, my Lord, my Lord

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Giue credit: I could wish time would stand still
And neuer end this enteruew this hower,
sp.stage: Zanche brings out a Carpet Spreads it and layes on it two faire Cushions Enter Cornelia
sp.l: But all delight doth it selfe soon'st dcuour.
Let me into your bosome happy Ladie,
Powre out in stead of eloquence my vowes,
Loose me not Madam, for if you forego me I am lost eternallie.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Sir in the way of pittie I wish you hart-hole.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: You are a sweet Phisition.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Sure Sir a loathed crueltie in Ladyes
Is as to Doctors many funeralls: It takes away their credit.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Excellent Creature.
Wee call the cruell fayre, what name for you
That are so mercifull?

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: See now they close.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Most happie vnion.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: My feares are falne vpon me, oh my heart!
My sonne the pandar: now I find our house
Sinking to ruine. Earth-quakes leaue behind,
Where they haue tyrannised, iron, or lead, or stone,
But woe to ruine violent lust leaues none

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: What valew is this Iewell

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Tis the ornament Of a weake fortune.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: In sooth ile haue it; nay I will but change
My Iewell for your Iewell.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Excellent,
His Iewell for her Iewell, well put in Duke.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Nay let me see you weare it.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Heare sir.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Nay lower, you shall weare my Iewell lower.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: That's better she must weare his Iewell lower.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: To passe away the time I'le tell your grace,
A dreame I had last night.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Most wishedly.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: A foolish idle dreame,
Me thought I walkt about the mid of night,
Into a Church-yard, where a goodly Eu Tree
Spred her large roote in ground, vnder that Eu,
As I sat sadly leaning on a graue,
Checkered with crosse-sticks, their came stealing in
Your Dutchesse and my husband, one of them
A picax bore, th'other a Rusty spade,
And in rough termes they gan to challenge me,
About this Eu.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: That Tree.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: This harmelesse Eu:
They told me my entent was to root vp
That well-growne Eu, and plant i'th steed of it
A withered blacke-thorne, and for that they vow'd
To bury me aliue: my husband straight
With picax gan to dig, and your fell Dutchesse
With shouell, like a fury, voyded out
The earth & scattered bones, Lord how me thought
I trembled, and yet for all this terror
I could not pray.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: No the diuell was in your dreame.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: When to my rescue there arose me thought
A whirlewind, which let fall a massy arme
From that strong plant,
And both were strucke dead by that sacred Eu
In that base shallow graue that was their due.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Excellent Diuell.
Shee hath taught him in a dreame
To make away his Dutchesse and her husband.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Sweetly shall I enterpret this your dreame,
You are lodged within his armes who shall protect you,
From all the feauers of a iealous husband,
From the poore enuy of our flegmaticke Dutchesse,
I'le seate you aboue law and aboue scandall,
Giue to your thoughts the inuention of delight
And the fruition, nor shall gouernment
Diuide me from you longer then a care
To keepe you great: you shall to me at once,
Be Dukedome, health, wife, children, friends and all.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Woe to light hearts they still forerun our fall.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: What fury rais'd thee vp? away, away

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: What make you heare my Lord this dead of night?
Neuer dropt meldew on a flower here, tell now.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: I pray will you go to bed then,
Least you be blasted.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O that this faire garden,
Had all poysoned hearbes of Thessaly,
At first bene planted, made a nursery
For witch-craft; rather a buriall plot,
For both your Honours.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Dearest mother heare me.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O thou dost make my brow bend to the earth,
Sooner then nature, see the curse of children
In life they keepe vs freqeuently in teares,
And in the cold graue leaues vs in pale feares.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Come, come, I will not heare you.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Deere my Lord.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Where is thy Dutchesse now adulterous Duke?
Thou little dreamd'st this night shee is come to Rome.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: How? come to Rome,

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: The Dutchesse,

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: She had bene better,

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: The liues of Princes should like dyals moue,
Whose regular example is so strong,
They make the times by them go right or wrong.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: So, haue you done?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Vnfortunate Camillo.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I do protest if any chast deniall,
If any thing but bloud could haue alayed,
His long suite to me.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: I will ioyne with thee,
To the most wofull end ere mother kneel'd,
If thou dishonour thus thy husbands bed,
Bee thy life short as are the funerall teares
In great mens.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Fye, fye, the womans mad.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Bee thy act Iudas-like betray in kissing,
Maiest thou be enuied during his short breath,
And pittied like a wretch after this death.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O me accurst.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Are you out of your wits, my Lord
Ile fetch her backe againe?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: No I'le to bed.
Send Doctor Iulio to me presently,
Vncharitable woman thy rash tongue
Hath rais'd a fearefull and prodigious storme,
Bee thou the cause of all ensuing harme.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Now, you that stand so much vpon your honour,
Is this a fitting time a night thinke you,
To send a Duke home without ere a man:
I would faine know where lies the masse of wealth
Which you haue whoorded for my maintenance,
That I may beare my beard out of the leuell
Of my Lords Stirop.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: What? because we are poore,
Shall we be vitious?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Pray what meanes haue you
To keepe me from the gallies, or the gallowes?
My father prou'd himselfe a Gentleman,
Sold als land, and like a fortunate fellow,
Died ere the money was spent. You brought me vp,
At Padua I confesse, where I protest
For want of meanes, the Vniuersity iudge me,
I haue bene faine to heele my Tutors stockings
At least seuen yeares: Conspiring with a beard
Made me a Graduate, then to this Dukes seruice,
I visited the Court, whence I return'd:
More courteous, more letcherous by farre,
But not a suite the richer, and shall I,
Hauing a path so open and so free
To my preferment, still retaine your milke
In my pale forehead, no this face of mine
I'le arme and fortefie with lusty wine,
Gainst shame and blushing.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O that I ne're had borne thee,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: So would I.
I would the common'st Courtezan in Rome,
Had bene my mother rather then thy selfe.
Nature is very pittfull to whoores
To giue them but few children, yet those children
Plurality of fathers, they are sure
They shall not want. Go, go,
Complaine vnto my great Lord Cardinall,
Yet may be he will iustifie the act.
Lycurgus wondred much men would prouide
Good stalions for their Mares, and yet would suffer
Their faire wiues to be barren,

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Misery of miseries.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: The Dutchesse come to Court, I like not that,
Wee are ingag'd to mischiefe and must on.
As Riuers to finde out the Ocean
Flow with crooke bendings beneath forced bankes,
Or as wee see to aspire some mountaines top,
The way ascends not straight, but Imitates
The suttle fouldings of a Winters snake,
So who knowes policy and her true aspect,
Shall finde her waies winding and indirect.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco de Medicis, Cardinall Mountcelso, Marcello, Isabella, young Giouanni, with little Iaques the Moore.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Haue you not seene your husband since you ariued?

sp.speaker: ISAB.
sp.l: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Surely he is wondrous kind,
If I had a such Doue-house as Camillo's
I would set fire on't, wer't but to destroy
The Pole-cats that haunt to't,— my sweet cossin.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Lord vnkle you did promise mee a horse
And armour.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: That I did my pretty cossin,
Marcello see it fitted.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: My Lord the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Sister away you must not yet bee seene.

sp.speaker: ISAB.
sp.l: I do beseech you intreate him mildely,
Let not your rough tongue
Set vs at louder variance, all my wrongs
Are freely pardoned, and I do not doubt
As men to try the precious Vnicornes horne
Make of the powder a preseruatiue Circle
And in it put a spider, so these armes
Shall charme his poyson, force it to obeying
And keepe him chast from an infected straying

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I wish it may. Be gone.
Void the chamber,
You are welcome, will you sit, I pray my Lord
Bee you my Orator, my hearts too full,
I'le second you anon.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: E're I beginne
Let me entreat your grace forgo all passion
Which may be raised by my free discourse:

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: As silent as i'th Church you may proceed.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: It is a wonder to your noble friends,
That you haue as 'twere entred the world,
With a free Scepter in your able hand,
And haue to th'use of nature well applyed
High gifts of learning, should in your prime-age
Neglect your awfull throne, for the soft downe
Of an insatiate bed. oh my Lord,
The Drunkard after all his lauish cuppes,
Is dry, and then is sober, so at length,
When you awake from this lasciuious dreame,
Repentance then will follow; like the sting
Plac't in the Adders tayle: wretched are Princes
When fortune blasteth but a petty flower
Of their vnweldy crownes; or rauesheth
But one pearle from their Scepter: but alas!
When they to wilfull shipwrake loose good Fame
All Princely titles perish with their name.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: You haue said my Lord,

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Inough to giue you tast
How farre I am from flattering your greatnesse?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Now you that are his second, what say you?
Do not like yong hawkes fetch a course about
Your game flies faire and for you,

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Do not feare it:
I'le answere you in your owne hawking phrase,
Some Eagles that should gaze vpon the Sunne
Seldome soare high, but take their lustfull ease,
Since they from dunghill birds their pery can ceaze,
You know Uittoria,

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: You shift your shirt there
When you retire from Tennis.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Happely.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Her husband is Lord of a poore fortune
Yet she wears cloth of Tissue,

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: What of this?
Will you vrge that my good Lord Cardinall
As part of her confession at next Shrift,
And know from whence it sailes.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: She is your Strumpet,

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Vnciuill sir ther's Hemlocke in thy breath
And that blacke slander, were she a whore of mine
All thy loud Cannons, and thy borrowed Switzers
Thy Gallies, nor thy sworne confederates,
Durst not supplant her.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Let's not talke on thunder,
Thou hast a wife, our sister, would I had giuen
Both her whitehands to death, bound and lockt fast
In her last winding sheere, when I gaue thee
But one.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Thou hadst giuen a soule to God then.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: True,
Thy ghostly father with als absolution,
Shall ne're do so by thee.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Spit thy poyson,

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I shall not need, lust carries her sharpe whippe
At her owne girdle, looke to't for our anger
Is making thunder-bolts.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Thunder? in faith,
They are but crackers.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Wee'le end this with the Cannon.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Thou'lt get nought by it but iron in thy wounds,
And gunpowder in thy nostrels.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Better that
Then change perfumes for plaisters,

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Pitty on thee,
'Twere good you'ld shew your slaues or men condemn'd
Your new plow'd fore-head defiance, and I'le meete thee,
Even in a thicket of thy ablest men.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: My Lords, you shall not word it any further
Without a milder limit.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Haue you proclaimed a Triumph that you baite a
Lyon thus.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: I am tame, I am tame sir.

sp.speaker: FLAN.
sp.l: We send, vnto the Duke for conference
Bout leauyes 'gainst the Pyrates, my Lord Duke
Is not at home, we come our selfe in person,
Still my Lord Duke is busied, but we feare
When Tyber to each proling passenger
Discouers flockes of wild-duckes, then my Lord
'Bout moulting time, I meane wee shall be certaine
To finde you sure enough and speake with you.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: FLAN.
sp.l: A meere tale of a tub, my wordes are idle,
But to expresse the Sonnet by naturall reason,
When Stagges grow melancholike you'le finde the season

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: No more my Lord, heare comes a Champion,
Shall end the difference betweene you both,
Your sonne the Prince Giouanni, see my Lords
What hopes you store in him, this is a casket
For both your Crowns, & should be held like deere:
Now is he apt for knowledge, therefore know
It is a more direct and euen way
To traine to vertue those of Princely bloud,
By examples then by precepts: if by examples
Whom should he rather striue to imitate
Then his owne father: be his patterne then,
Leaue him a stocke of vertue that may last,
Should fortune rend his sailes, and split his mast.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Your hand boy growing to souldier.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Giue me a pike.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: What practising your pike so yong, faire cous.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Suppose me one of Homers frogges, my Lord,
Tossing my bul-rush thus, pray sir tell mee
Might not a child of good descretion
Be leader to an army:

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Yes cousin a yong Prince
Of good descretion might.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Say you so,
Indeed I haue heard 'tis fit a Generall
Should not endanger his owne person oft,
So that he make a noyse, when hee's a horsebacke
Like a danske drummer, ô 'tis excellent.
Hee need not fight, me thinkes his horse as well
Might lead an army for him; if I liue
I'le charge the French foe, in the very front
Of all my troupes, the formost man.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: What, what,

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: And will not bid my Souldiers vp and follow
But bid them follow me.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Forward Lap-wing.
He flies with the shell on's head.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Pretty cousin,

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: The first yeare vnkle that I go to warre,
All prisoners that I take I will set free
Without their ransome.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Ha, without thier ransome,
How then will you reward your souldiers
That tooke those prisoners for you.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Thus my Lord,
I'le marry them to all the wealthy widowes
That fals that yeare.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Why then the next yeare following
You'le haue no men to go with you to warre.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Why then I'le presse the women to the war,
And then the men will follow.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Witty Prince.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: See a good habite makes a child a man,
Whereas a bad one makes a man a beast:
Come you and I are friends.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Most wishedly,
Like bones which broke in sunder and well set
Knit the more strongly.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Call Camillo hither
You haue receiued the rumor, how Count Lodowicke
Is turn'd a Pyrate.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: We are now preparing,
Some shippes to fetch him in: behold your Dutchesse,
Wee now will leaue you and expect from you
Nothing but kind intreaty.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: You haue charm'd mee.
You are in health we see.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: And aboue health
To see my Lord well,

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: So I wonder much,
What amorous whirlewind hurryed you to Rome

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Deuotion my Lord.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Deuotion?
Is your soule charg'd with any grieuous sinne

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: 'Tis burdened with too many, and I thinke
The oftner that we cast our reckonings vp,
Our sleepes will be the sounder.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Take your chamber?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Nay my deere Lord I will not haue you angry,
Doth not my absence from you two moneths,
Merit one kisse?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: I do not vse to kisse,
If that will dispossesse your iealousy,
I'le sweare it to you.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: O my loued Lord,
I do not come to chide; my iealousy,
I am to learne what that Italian meanes,
You are as welcome to these longing armes,
As I to you a Virgine.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: O your breath,
Out vpon sweete meates, and continued Physicke.
The plague is in them.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: You haue oft for these two lippes
Neglected Cassia or the naturall sweetes
Of the Spring-violet, they are not yet much whithered,
My Lord I should be merry, these your frownes
Shew in a Helmet, louely but on me,
In such a peacefull enterueiw me thinkes
They are to too roughly knit.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: O dissemblance.
Do you bandy factions gainst me? haue you learn't,
The trick of impudent basenes to complaine
Vnto your kindred?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Neuer my deere Lord.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Must I be haunted out, or wast your trick
To meete some amorous gallant heere in Rome
That must supply our discontinuance?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: I pray sir burst my heart, and in my death
Turne to your antient pitty, though not loue.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Because your brother is the corpulent Duke,
That is the great Duke, S'death I shall not shortly
Rackit away fiue hundreth Crownes at Tenis,
But it shall rest vpon record: I scorne him
Like a shau'd Pollake, all his reuerent wit
Lies in his wardrope, hee's a discret fellow
When hee's made vp in his roabes of state,
Your brother the great Duke, because h'as gallies,
And now and then ransackes a Turkish flye-boate,
(Now all the hellish furies take his soule,)
First made this match, accursed be the Priest
That sang the wedding Masse, and euen my Issue.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: O to too far you haue curst.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Your hand I'le kisse,
This is the latest ceremony of my loue,
Hence-forth I'le neuer lye with thee, by this,
This wedding-ring: I'le ne'remore lye with thee.
And this diuorce shall be as truely kept,
As if the Iudge had doom'd it: fare you well,
Our sleeps are seuer'd.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Forbid it the sweet vnion
Of all things blessed; why the Saints in heauen
Will knit their browes at that.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Let not thy loue,
Make thee an vnbeleeuer, this my vow,
Shall neuer on my soule bee satisfied
With my repentance: let thy brother rage
Beyond a horred tempest or sea-fight,
My vow is fixed.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: O my winding sheet,
Now shall I need thee shortly, deere my Lord,
Let me heare once more, what I would not heare,
Neuer.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Neuer?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: O my vnkind Lord may your sins find mercy,
As I vpon a woefull widowed bed,
Shall pray for you, if not to turne your eyes,
Vpon your wretched wife, and hopefull sonne,
Yet that in time you'le fix them vpon heauen.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: No more, go, go, complaine to the great Duke.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: No my deere Lord, you shall haue present witnesse,
How I'le worke peace betweene you, I will make
My selfe the author of your cursed vow
I haue some cause to do it, you haue none,
Conceale it I beseech you, for the weale
Of both your Dukedomes, that you wrought the meanes
Of such a separation, let the fault
Remaine with my supposed iealousy,
And thinke with what a pitteous and rent hear,
I shall performe this sad insuing part.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, Flamineo, Montcello, Marcello, Camillo.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Well, take your course my honourable brother.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Sister, this is not well my Lord, why sister,
She merits not this welcome.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Welcome say?
Shee hath giuen a sharpe welcome.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Are you foolish?
Come dry your teares, is this a modest course.
To better what is nought, to raile and weepe,
Grow to a reconcilement, or by heauen,
I'le nere more deale betweene you.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Sir you shall not,
No though Uittoria vpon that condition
Would become honest.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Was your husband loud.
Since we departed.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: By my life sir no,
I sweare by that I do not care to loose.
Are all these ruines of my former beauty,
Laid out for a whores triumph?

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Do you heare
Looke vpon other women, with what patience
They suffer these slight wrongs, with what iustice
They study to requite them, take that course.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: O that I were a man, or that I had power
To execute my apprehended wishes,
I would whip some with scorpions.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: What? turn'd fury?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: To dig the strumpets eyes out, let her lye
Some twenty monethes a dying, to cut off
Her nose and lippes, pull out her rotten teeth,
Preserue her flesh like Mummia, for trophies
Of my iust anger: Hell to my affliction
Is meere snow-water, by your fauour sir,
Brother draw neere, and my Lord Cardinall,
Sir let me borrow of you but one kisse,
Hence-forth I'le neuer lye with you, by this,
This wedding ring.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How? nere more lie with him,

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: And this diuorce shall be as truly kept,
As if in thronged Court, a thousand eares
Had heard it, and a thousand Lawyers hands,
Seal'd to the separation.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Nere lie with me?

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: Let not my former dotage,
Make thee an vnbeleuer, this my vow
Shall neuer on my soule be satisfied
With my repentance, manet alta mente repositum.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Now by my birth you are a foolish, mad,
And iealous woman.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: You see 'tis not my seeking.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Was this your circle of pure Vnicornes horne,
You said should charme your Lord; now hornes vpon thee,
For iealousy deserues them, keepe your vow,
And take your chamber.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: No sir I'le presently to Padua,
I will not stay a minute.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: O good Madame.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: 'Twere best to let her haue her humor.
Some halfe daies iourney will bring downe her stomacke,
And then she'le turne in post.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: To see her come,
To my Lord Cardinall for a dispensation
Of her rash vow will beget excellent laughter.

sp.speaker: ISA.
sp.l: "Vnkindnesse do thy office, poore heart breake,
" Those are the killing greifes which dare not speake.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Camill's come my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Where's the commission?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Tis here.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Giue me the Signet.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: My Lord do you marke their whispering, I will compound a medicine out of their two heads, stronger then garlick, deadlier then stibium, the Cantarides which are scarce seene to sticke vpon the flesh when they work to the heart, shall not do it with more silence or inuisible cunning.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: About the murder.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: They are sending him to Naples, but I'le send him to Candy, her's another property to.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: O the Doctor,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: A poore quackesaluing knaue, my Lord, one that should haue bene lasht for's letchery, but that he confest a iudgement, had an execution laid vpon him, and so put the whip to a non-plus.

sp.speaker: DOCT.
sp.p: And was consin'd, my Lord, by an arranter knaue then my selfe, and made pay all the coulourable execution.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: He will shoot pils into a mans guts, shall make them haue more ventages then a cornet or a lamprey, hee will poyson a kisse, and was once minded, for his Master-peece, because Ireland breeds no poyson, to haue prepared a deadly vapour in a Spaniards fart that should haue poison'd all Dublin.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: O Saint Anthony fire:

sp.speaker: DOCT.
sp.l: Your Secretary is merry my Lord:

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p:
O thou cursed antipathy to nature, looke his eyes bloud-shed like a needle a Chirurgeon stitcheth a wound with, let me embrace thee toad, & loue thee ô thou abhominable lothsome gargarisme, that will fetch vp lungs, lights, heart, and liuer
by scruples.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: No more, I must employ thee honest Doctor,
You must to Padua and by the way, vse some of your skil for vs.

sp.speaker: DOC.
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: But for Camillo?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: He dies this night by such a polliticke straine,
Men shall suppose him by's owne engine slaine.
But for your Dutchesse death.

sp.speaker: DOCT.
sp.l: I'le make her sure

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Small mischiefes are by greater made secure.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: Remember this you slaue, when knaues come to preferment they rise as gallouses are raised i'th low countries, one vpon another shoulders.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Here is an Embleme nephew pray peruse it.
'Twas throwne in at your window,

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: At my window,
Here is a Stag my Lord hath shed his hornes,
And for the losse of them the poore beast weepes
The word Inopem me copia fecit.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: That is.
Plenty of hornes hath made him poore of hornes.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: What should this meane.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Ile tell you, 'tis giuen out
You are a Cocould.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Is it giuen out so.
I had rather such report as that my Lord.
Should keepe within dores.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Haue you any children.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: You are the happier
Ile tell you a tale.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Pray my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: An old tale.
Vppon a time Phoebus the God of light
Or him wee call the Sunne would neede be married.
The Gods gaue their consent, and Mercury
Was sent to voice it to the generall world.
But what a pitious cry their straight arose
Amongst Smiths, & Felt-makers, Brewers & Cooks.
Reapers and Butter-women, amongst Fishmongers
And thousand other trades, which are annoyed
By his excessiue heate; twas lamentable.
They came to Iupiter all in a sweat
And do forbid the banes; a great fat Cooke
Was made their Speaker, who intreates of Ioue
That Phoebus might bee guelded, for if now
When there was but one, Sunne so many men,
Weare like to perish by his violent heate.
What should they do if hee were married
And should beget more, and those children
Make fier-workes like their father, so say I,
Only I will apply it to your wife,
Her issue should not prouidence preuent it
Would make both nature, time, and man repent it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Looke you cossin.
Go change the aire for shame see if your absence,
Will blast your Cornucopia, Marcello
Is chosen with you ioint commissioner
For the relieuing our Italian coast
From pirats.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: I am much honord int.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: But sir
Ere I returne the Stagges hornes may be sprouted,
Greater then these are shed.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Do not feare it,
I'le bee your ranger.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: You must watch i'ch nights,
Then's the most danger.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Farewell good Marcello.
All the best fortunes of a Souldiers wish,
Bring you a ship-board.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Were I not best now I am turn'd Souldier,
E're that I leaue my wife, sell all shee hath,
And then take leaue of her.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: I expect good from you,
Your parting is so merry.

sp.speaker: CAM.
sp.l: Merry my Lord, a'th Captaines humor right
I am resolued to be drunke this night.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: So, 'twas well fitted, now shall we descerne,
How his wisht absence will giue violent way,
To Duke Brachiano's lust,

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Why that was it;
To what scorn'd purpose else should we make choice
Of him for a sea Captaine, and besides,
Count Lodowicke which was rumor'd for a pirate.
Is now in Padua.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Is't true?

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Most certaine.
I haue letters from him, which are suppliant
To worke his quicke repeale from banishment,
He meanes to adresse himselfe for pention,
Vnto our sister Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: O 'twas well.
We shall not want his absence past sixe daies,
I faine would haue the Duke Brachiano run
Into notorious scandale, for their's nought
In such curst dotage, to repaire his name,
Onely the deepe sence of some deathlesse shame:

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: It may be obiected I am dishonourable,
To play thus with my kinsman, but I answere.
For my reuenge I'de stake a brothers life,
That being wrong'd durst not auenge himselfe.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Come to obserue this Strumper.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Cursse of greatnes,
Sure hee'le not leaue her.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: There's small pitty in't
Like mistle-tow on seare Elmes spent by weather,
Let him cleaue to her and both rot together.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano with one in the habite of a Coniurer.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Now sir I claime your promise, 'tis dead midnight,
The time prefixt to shew me by your Art,
How the intended murder of Camillo,
And our loathed Dutchesse grow to action.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: You haue won me by your bounty to a deed,
I do not often practise, some there are,
Which by Sophisticke tricks, aspire that name
Which I would gladly loose, of Nigromancer:
As some that vse to iuggle vpon cardes,
Seeming to coniure, when indeed they cheate.
Others that raise vp their confederate spirits,
'Bout wind-mils, and indanger their owne neckes,
For making of a squib, and some their are
Will keepe a curtall to shew iuggling trickes
And giue out 'tis a spirit: besides these
Such a whole reame of Almanacke-makers, figure-flingers.
Fellowes indeed that onely liue by stealth,
Since they do meerely lie about stolne goods,
Thei'd make men thinke the diuell were fast and loose,
With speaking fustian Lattine: pray sit downe,
Put on this night-cap sir, 'tis charm'd, and now
I'le shew you by my strong-commanding Art
The circumstance that breakes your Dutchsse heart.
sp.stage: Enter suspiciously, Iulio and Christophero, they draw a curtains wher Brachian's picture is, they put on spectacles of glasse, which couer their eyes and noses, and then burne perfumnes afore the picture, and wash the lips of the picture, that done, quenching the fire, and putting off their spectacles they depart laughing.

Enter Isabella in her night-gowne as to did-ward, with lights after her, Count Lodouico, Giouanni, Guid-antonio and others waighting on her, shee kneeles downe as to prayers, then drawes the curtaine of the picture, doe's three reuerences to it, and kisses it thrice, shee faints and will not suffer them to come nere it, dies, sorrow exprest in Giouanni and in Count Lodouico, shees conueid out solemnly.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Excellent, then shee's dead,

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: She's poysoned,
By the fum'd picture, 'twas her custome nightly,
Before shee went to bed, to go and visite
Your picture, and to feed her eyes and lippes
On the dead shadow, Doctor Iulio
Obseruing this, infects it with an oile
And other poison'd stuffe, which presently
Did suffocate her spirits.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Me thought I saw,
Count Lodowicke there.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: He was, and by my art
I finde hee did most passionately doate
Vpon your Dutchesse, now turne another way,
And view Camillo's farre more polliticke face,
Strike louder musicke from this charmed ground,
To yeeld, as fits the act, a Tragicke sound.
sp.stage:
Enter Flamineo, Marcello, Camillo, with foure more as Captaines, they drinke healths and dance, a vauting horse is brought into the roome, Marcello and two more whisper'd out of the roome, while Flamineo and Camillo strip themselues into their shirts, as to vault, complement who shall beginne, as Camillo it about to vault, Flamineo pitcheth him vpon his necke, and with the help of the rest, wriths his necke about, seeme's to see if it be broke, and layes him foulded double as 'twere vnder the herse, makes showes to call for helpe.
Marcello comes in, laments, sends for the Cardinall and Duke, who comes forth with armed men, wonder at the act, commands the bodie to be carried home, apprehends Flamineo, Marcello, and the rest, and go as 'twere to apprehend Vittoria.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: 'Twas quaintly done, but yet each circumstance,
I tast not fully.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: O 'twas most apparant,
You saw them enter charged with their deepe helthes
To their boone voyage, and to second that,
Flamineo cals to haue a vaulting horse
Maintaine their sport. The vertuous Marcello,
Is innocently plotted forth the roome,
Whilst your eye saw the rest, and can informe you
The engine of all.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: It seemes Marcello, and Flamineo
Are both committed.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: Yes, you saw them guarded,
And now they are come with purpose to apprehend
Your Mistresse, faire Uittoria; wee are now
Beneath her roofe: 'twere fit we instantly
Make out by some backe posterne:

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Noble friend,
You bind me euer to you, this shall stand
As the firme seale annexed to my hand.
It shall inforce a payment.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.l: Sir I thanke you.
Both flowers and weedes, spring when the Sunne is warme,
And great men do great good, or else great harme.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, and Monticelso, their Chancellor and Register.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: You haue dealt discreetly to obtaine the presence,
Of all the graue Leiger Embassadours
To heare Vittorias triall.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: 'Twas not ill,
For sir you know we haue nought but circumstances
To charge her with, about her husbands death,
Their approbation therefore to the proofes
Of her blacke lust, shall make her infamous
To all our neighbouring Kingdomes, I wonder (pable
If Brachiano will be here.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: O fye 'twere impudence too pal-
sp.stage: Enter Flamineo and Marcello guarded, and a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.p:
What are you in by the weeke, so I will try now
whether thy wit be close prisoner, mee thinke's none should sit vpon thy sister but old whoore-maisters,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: Or cocoulds, for your cocould is your most terrible tickler of letchery: whoore-maisters would serue, for none are iudges at tilting, but those that haue bene old Tilters.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: My Lord Duke and shee haue bene very priuate:

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: You are a dull asse, 'tis threatned they haue bene very publicke.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: If it can be proued they haue but kist one another.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: My Lord Cardinall will ferit them,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: A Cardinall I hope will not catch conyes.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.p: For to sowe kisses (marke what I say) to sowe kisses, is to reape letchery, and I am sure a woman that will endure kissing is halfe won.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: True, her vpper part by that rule, if you will win her nether part to, you know what followes.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: Harke the Embassadours are lighted,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: I do put on this feigned Garbe of mirth,
To gull suspition.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: O my vnfortunate sister!
I would my daggers point had cleft her heart
When she first saw Brachiano: You 'tis said,
Were made his engine, and his stauking horse
To vndo my sister.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: I made a kind of path
To her & mine owne preferment.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Your ruine,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Hum! thou art a souldier,
Followest the great Duke, feedest his victories,
As witches do their seruiceable spirits,
Euen with thy prodigall bloud, what hast got?
But like the wealth of Captaines, a poore handfull,
Which in thy palme thou bear'st, as men hold water
Seeking to gripe it fast, the fraile reward
Steales through thy fingers.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Thou hast scarce maintenance
To keepe thee in fresh shamoyes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Heare me,
And thus when we haue euen powred ourselues,
Into great fights, for their ambition
Or idle spleene, how shall we find reward,
But as we seldome find the mistle-towe
Sacred to physicke: Or the builder Oke,
Without a Mandrake by it, so in our quest of gaine.
Alas the poorest of their forc'd dislikes
At a limbe proffers, but at heart it strikes:
This is lamented doctrine.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: When age shall turne thee,
White as a blooming hauthorne.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: I'le interrupt you.
For loue of vertue beare an honest heart,
And stride ouer euery polliticke respect,
Which where they most aduance they most infect.
Were I your father, as I am your brother,
I should not be ambitious to leaue you
A better patrimony.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I'le think on't, The Lord Embassadors.
sp.stage: Here there is a passage of the Lieger Embassadours ouer the Stage seuerally. Enter French Embassadours.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.p: O my sprightly Frenchman, do you know him, he's an admirable Tilter.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: I saw him at last Tilting, he shewed like a peuter candlesticke fashioned like a man in armour, houlding a Tilting staffe in his hand, little bigger then a candle of twelue i'th pound.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: O but he's an excellent horseman.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: A lame one in his lofty trickes, hee sleepes a horsebacke like a poulter,

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: Lo you my Spaniard.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: He carries his face in's ruffe, as I haue seene a seruingman carry glasses in a cipres hat-band, monstrous steddy for feare of breaking, He lookes like the claw of a blacke-bird, first salted and then broyled in a candle.
sp.stage: THE ARAIGNEMENT OF VITTORIA. Enter Francisco, Montcelso, the sixe lieger Embassadours, Brachiano, Uittoria, Isabella, Lawyer, and a guard.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Forbeare my Lord, here is no place assing'd you,
This businesse by his holinesse is left
To our examination.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: May it thriue with you.
sp.stage: Laies a rich gowne vnder him,

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: A Chaire there for his Lordship.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Forbeare your kindnesse, an vnbidden guest
Should trauaile as dutch-women go to Church:
Beare their stooles with them.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: At your pleasure Sir.
Stand to the table gentlewomen: now Signior
Fall to your plea.
sp.stage: Domine Iudex conuerte oculos in hanc pestem mulierum corruptissimam.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: A Lawyer, that pleades against you.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Pray my Lord, Let him speake his vsuall tongue
Ile make no answere else.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Why you vnderstand lattin.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I do Sir, but amongst this auditory
Which come to heare my cause, the halfe or more
May bee ignorant int'.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Go on Sir:

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: By your fauour,
I will not haue my accusation clouded,
In a strange tongue: All this assembly
Shall heare what you can charge mee with.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Signior.
You need not stand on't much; pray change your language,

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Oh for God sake: gentlewoman, your credit
Shall bee more famous by it.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: Well then haue at you.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I am at the marke Sir, Ile giue aime to you,
And tell you how neare you shoote.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: Most literated Iudges, please your Lordships,
So to conniue your Iudgements to the view
Of this debausht and diuersiuolent woman
Who such a blacke concatenation
Of mischiefe hath effected, that to exterpe
The memory of't, must be the consummation
Of her and her proiections

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: What's all this

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: Hould your peace.
Exorbitant sinnes must haue exulceration.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Surely my Lords this lawier here hath swallowed
Some Poticaryes bils, or proclamations.
And now the hard and vndegestable wordes,
Come vp like stones wee vse giue Haukes for phisicke.
Why this is welch to Lattin.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: My Lords, the woman
Know's not her tropes nor figures, nor is perfect
In the accademick deriuation
Of Grammaticall elocution.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Sir your paynes
Shall bee well spared, and your deepe eloquence
Bee worthely applauded amongst those
Which vnderstand you.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Sir,
Put vp your papers in your fustian bag,
sp.stage: Francisco speakes this as in scorne.
sp.l: Cry mercy Sir, tis buckeram, and accept
My notion of your learn'd verbosity.

sp.speaker: LAW.
sp.l: I most graduatically thanke your Lordship.
I shall haue vse for them elswhere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I shall bee playner with you, and paint out
Your folies in more naturall red and white.
Then that vpon your cheeke.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O you mistake.
You raise a blood as noble in this cheeke
As euer was your mothers.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I must spare you till proofe cry whore to that,
Obserue this creature here my honoured Lords,
A woman of a most prodigious spirit
In her effected.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Honorable my Lord,
It doth not sute a reuerend Cardinall
To play the Lawier thus

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Oh your trade instructs your language!
You see my Lords what goodly fruict she seemes,
Yet like those apples trauellers report
To grow where Sodom and Gomora stood.
I will but touch her and you straight shall see
Sheele fall to soote and ashes.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Your inuenom'd Poticary should doo't

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I am resolued.
Were there a second Paradice to loose
This Deuell would betray it.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O poore charity!
Thou art seldome found in scarlet.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Who knowes not how, when seuerall night by night
Her gates were choak'd with coaches, and her roomes.
Out-brau'd the stars with seuerall kind of lights,
When shee did counterfet a Princes Court.
In musicke banquets and most ryotous surfets
This whore, forsooth, was holy.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Ha? whore what's that?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Shall I expound whore to you? sure I shal;
Ile giue their perfect character. They are first,
Sweete meates which rot the eater: In mans nostrill
Poison'd perfumes. They are coosning Alcumy,
Shipwrackes in Calmest weather? What are whores?
Cold Russian winters, that appeare so barren,
As if that nature had forgot the spring.
They are the trew matteriall fier of hell,
Worse then those tributes ith low countries payed,
Exactions vpon meat, drinke, garments sleepe.
I euen on mans perdition, his sin.
They are those brittle euidences of law
Which forfait all a wretched mans estate
For leauing out one sillable. What are whores?
They are those flattering bels haue all one tune:
At weddings, and at funerals, your ritch whores
Are only treasuries by extortion fild,
And empted by curs'd riot. They are worse,
Worse then dead bodies, which are beg'd at gallowes
And wrought vpon by surgeons, to teach man
Wherin hee is imperfect. Whats a whore?
Shees like the guilty conterfetted coine
Which who so eare first stampes it bring in trouble
All that receaue it

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: This carracter scapes me.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: You gentlewoman;
Take from all beasts, and from all mineralls
Their deadly poison.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Well what then?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Ile tell thee
Ile find in thee a Poticaries shop
To sample them all.

sp.speaker: FR. EMB.
sp.l: Shee hath liued ill.

sp.speaker: ENG. and EMB.
sp.l: Trew, but the Cardinals too bitter.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: You know what Whore is next the deuell; Adultry.
Enters the deuell, murder.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Your vnhappy husband
Is dead.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O hee's a happy husband
Now hee owes Nature nothing.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: And by a vaulting engine.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: An actiue plot
Hee iumpt into his graue.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: what a prodigy wast,
That from some two yardes height a slender man (more,
Should breake his necke?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Ith' rushes.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: And what's.
Vpon the instant loose all vse of speach,
All vitall motion, like a man had laine
Wound vp three dayes. Now marke each circumstance.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: And looke vpon this creature was his wife.
Shee comes not like a widow: shee comes arm'd
With scorne and impudence: Is this a mourning habit.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Had I forknowne his death as you suggest,
I would haue bespoke my mourning.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: O you are conning.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: You shame your wit and Iudgement
To call it so; What is my iust defence
By him that is my Iudge cal'd impudence?
Let mee appeale then from this Christian Court
To the vnciuill Tartar.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: See my Lords.
Shee scandals our proceedings.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Humbly thus.
Thus low, to the most worthy and respected
Leigier Embassadors, my modesty
And womanhood I tender; but withall
So intangled in a cursed accusation
That my defence of force like Perseus.
Must personate masculine vertue to the point.
Find mee but guilty, seuer head from body:
Weele part good frindes: I scorne to hould my life.
at yours or any mans intreaty, Sir,

sp.speaker: ENG. EMB.
sp.l: Shee hath a braue spirit

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Well, well, such counterfet Iewels
Make trew on's oft suspected.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: You are deceaued.
For know that all your strickt combined heads,
Which strike against this mine of diamondes,
Shall proue but glassen hammers, they shall breake,
These are but faigned shadowes of my euels.
Terrify babes, my Lord, with painted deuils,
I am past such needlesse palsy, for your names,
Of Whoore and Murdresse they proceed from you,
As if a man should spit against the wind,
The filth returne's in's face.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Pray you Mistresse satisfy me one question:
Who lodg'd beneath your roofe that fatall night
Your husband brake his necke?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: That question
Inforceth me breake silence, I was there.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Your businesse?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Why I came to comfort her,
And take some course for setling her estate,
Because I heard her husband was in debt
To you my Lord.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: He was.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: And 'twas strangely fear'd,
That you would cosen her.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Who made you ouer-seer?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Why my charity, my charity, which should flow
From euery generous and noble spirit,
To orphans and to widdows.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Your lust.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Cowardly dogs barke loudest. Sirrah Priest,
Ile talke with you hereafter,— Do you heare?
The sword you frame of such an excellent temper,
I'le sheath in your owne bowels:
There are a number of thy coate resemble
Your common post-boyes.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Your mercinary post-boyes,
Your letters carry truth, but 'tis your guise
To fill your mouth's with grosse and impudent lies.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: My Lord your gowne.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Thou liest 'twas my stoole.
Bestow't vpon thy maister that will challenge
The rest a'th houshold-stuffe for Brachiano
Was nere so beggarly, to take a stoole
Out of anothers lodging: let him make
Valence for his bed on't, or a demy foote-cloth,
For his most reuerent moile, Monticelso,
Nemo me Impune lacescit.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Your Champions gon.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: The wolfe may prey the better.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: My Lord there's great suspition of the murder,
But no sound proofe who did it: for my part
I do not thinke she hath a soule so blacke
To act a deed so bloudy, if shee haue,
As in cold countries husband-men plant Vines,
And with warme bloud manure them, euen so
One summer she will beare vnsauory fruite,
And ere next spring wither both branch and roote.
The act of bloud let passe, onely descend,
To matter of incontinence.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I decerne poison,
Vnder your guilded pils.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Now the Duke's gone, I wil produce a letter,
Wherein 'twas plotted, her and you should meete,
At an Appoticaries summer-house.
Downe by the riuer Tiber: veiw't my Lords:
Where after wanton bathing and the heat
Of a lasciuious banquet.— I pray read it,
I shame to speak the rest.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Grant I was tempted,
Temptation to lust proues not the act,
Cast a est quam nemo rogauit,
You reade his hot loue to me, but you want
My frosty answere.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Frost i'th dog-daies! strange!

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Condemne you me for that the Duke did loue mee,
So may you blame so me faire and christall riuer
For that some melancholike distracted man,
Hath drown'd himselfe in't.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Truly drown'd indeed.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Summe vp my faults I pray, and you shall finde,
That beauty and gay clothes, a merry heart,
And a good stomacke to feast, are all,
All the poore crimes that you can charge me with:
Infaith my Lord you might go pistoll flyes,
The sport would be more noble.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: But take you your course, it seemes you haue beggerd me
And now would faine vndo me, I haue houses, (first
Iewels, and a poore remnant of Crusado's,
Would those would make you charitable.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: If the deuill
Did euer take good shape behold his picture.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: You haue one vertue left,
You will not flatter me.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Who brought this letter?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I am not compel'd to tell you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: My Lord Duke sent to you a thousand duckets,
The twelfth of August.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: 'Twas to keepe your cosen
From prison, I paid vse for't.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I rather thinke
'Twas Interest for his lust.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Who saies so but your selfe? if you bee my accuser
Pray cease to be my Iudge, come from the Bench,
Giue in your euidence 'gainst me, and let these
Be moderators: my Lord Cardinall,
Were your intelligencing eares as louing
As to my thoughts, had you an honest tongue
I would not care though you proclaim'd them all.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Go to, go to.
After your goodly and vaine-glorious banquet,
I'le giue you a choake peare.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: A'your owne grafting?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: You were borne in Uenice, honourably descended,
From the Vittelli, 'twas my cossins fate,
Ill may I name the hower to marry you,
Hee bought you of your father.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Hee spent there in sixe monthes
Twelue thousand Dukets, and to my acquaintance
Receiu'd in dowry with you not one Iulio:
'Twas a hard peny-worth, the ware being so light,
I yet but draw the curtaine now to your picture,
You came from thence a most notorious strumpet,
And so you haue continued.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Nay heare me,
You shall haue time to prate my Lord Brachiano,
Alas I make but repetition,
Of what is ordinary and Ryalto talke,
And ballated, and would bee plaid a'th stage,
But that vice many times findes such loud freinds.
That Preachers are charm'd silent.
You Gentlemen Flamineo and Marcello,
The Court hath nothing now to charge you with,
Onely you must remaine vpon your suerties,
For your appearance.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: I stand for Marcello.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And my Lord Duke for me.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: For you Vittoria, your publicke fault,
Ioyn'd to'th condition of the present time,
Takes from you all the fruits of noble pitty.
Such a corrupted triall haue you made
Both of your life and beauty, and bene stil'd
No lesse in ominous fate then blasing starres
To Princes .Hear your sentence, you are confin'd,

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Vnto a house of conuertites and your baud.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Who I?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: The Moore.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O I am a sound man againe.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: A house of conuertites, what's that?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: A house of penitent whoores.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Do the Noblemen in Rome,
Erect it for their wiues, that I am sent
To lodge there?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: You must haue patience.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I must first haue vengeance.
I faine would know if you haue your saluation
By patent, that you proceed thus.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Away with her?
Take her hence.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: A rape, a rape.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Yes you haue rauisht iustice,
Forc't her to do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: fy shee's mad

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Dye with these pils in your most cursed mawes,
Should bring you: health, or while you sit a'th Bench,
Let your owne spittle choake you.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: She's turn'd fury.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: That the last day of iudgement may so find you,
And leaue you the same deuill you were before,
Instruct me some good horse-lech to speak Treason,
For since you cannot take my life for deeds,
Take it for wordes, ô womans poore reuenge
Which dwels but in the tongue, I will not weepe,
No I do scorne to call vp one poore teare
To fawne one your iniustice, beare me hence,
Vnto this house of what's your mittigating Title?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Of conuertites.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: It shal not be a house of conuertites
My minde shall make it honester to mee
Then the Popes Pallace, and more peaceable
Then thy soule, though thou art a Cardinall,
Know this, and let it some what raise your spight,
Through darkenesse Diamonds spred their ritchest light.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Now you and I are friends sir, wee'le shake hands,
In a friends graue, together, a fit place,
Being the embleme of soft peace t'attone our hatred.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: I will not chase more bloud from that lou'd checke,
You haue lost too much already, fare-you-well.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How strange these words sound? what's the interpretation?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Good, this is a preface to the discouery of the Dutches death: Hee carries it well: because now I cannot counterfeit a whining passion for the death of my Lady, I will faine a madde humor for the disgrace of my sister, and that will keepe off idle questions, Treasons tongue hath a villanous palsy in't, I will talk to any man, heare no man, and for a time appeare a polliticke mad-man.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How now my Noble cossin, what in blacke?

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Yes Vnckle, I was taught to imitate you
In vertue, and you must imitate mee
In couloures for your garments, my sweete mother
Is,

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How? Where?

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Is there, no yonder, indeed sir I'le not tell you,
For I shall make you weepe.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Is dead.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Do not blame me now,
I did not tell you so.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: She's dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Blessed Lady;
Thou art now aboue thy woes,
Wilt please your Lordships to with-draw a little.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: What do the dead do, vncle? do they eate,
Heare musicke, goe a hunting, and bee merrie, as wee that liue?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: No cose; they sleepe.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Lord, Lord, that I were dead,
I haue not slept these sixe nights. When doe they wake?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: When God shall please.
Good God let her sleepe euer.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: For I haue knowne her wake an hundreth nights,
When all the pillow, where shee laid her head,
Was brine-wet with her teares. I am to complaine to you Sir.
Ile tell you how they haue vsed her now shees dead:
They wrapt her in a cruell fould of lead,
And would not let mee kisse her.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Thou didst loue her.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: I haue often heard her say shee gaue mee sucke,
And it should seeme by that shee deerely lou'd mee,
Since Princes seldome doe it.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: O, all of my poore sister that remaines!
Take him away for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: How now my Lord?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Beleeue mee I am nothing but her graue,
And I shall keepe her blessed memorie,
Longer then thousand Epitaphs.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Wee indure the strokes like anuiles or hard steele,
Till paine it selfe make vs no paine to feele.
sp.p: Who shall doe mee right now? Is this the end of seruice? Ide rather go weede garlicke; trauaile through France, and be mine owne ostler; weare sheepe-skin lininges; or shoos that stinke of blacking; bee entred into the list of the fourtie thousand pedlars in Poland.
Would I had rotted in some Surgeons house at Venice, built vpon the Pox as well as on piles, ere I had seru'd Brachiano.

sp.speaker: SAV.
sp.l: You must haue comfort.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Your comfortable wordes are like honie. They rellish well in your mouth that's whole; but in mine that's wounded they go downe as if the sting of the Bee were in them. Oh they haue wrought their purpose cunningly, as if they would not seeme to doe it of malice. In this a Polititian imitates the deuill, as the deuill imitates a Canon. Wheresoeuer he comes to doe mischiefe, he comes with his backside towardes you.

sp.speaker: FRE.
sp.l: The proofes are euident.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p:
Proofe! t'was corruption. O Gold, what a God art thou! and ô man, what a deuill art thou to be tempted by that
cursed Minerall! You diuersiuolent Lawyer; marke him, knaues turne informers, as maggots turne to flies, you may catch gudgions with either. A Cardinall; I would hee would heare mee, theres nothing so holie but mony will corrupt and putrifie it, like vittell vnder the liue. You are happie in England, my Lord; here they sell iustice with those weights they presse men to death with. O horrible salarie!

sp.speaker: ENG.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Flamineo.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Bels nere ring well, till they are at their full pitch, And I hope yon Cardinall shall neuer haue the grace to pray well, till he come to the scaffold.

If they were rackt now to know the confederacie! But your Noblemen are priuiledged from the racke; and well may. For a little thing would pull some of them a peeces afore they came to their arraignement. Religion; oh how it is commeddled with policie. The first bloudshed in the world happened about religion. Would I were a Iew.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: O, there are too many.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd. There are not Iewes enough;
Priests enough, nor gentlemen enough.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Ile proue it. For if there were Iewes enough, so many Christians would not turne vsurers; if Preists enough, one should not haue sixe Benefices; and if gentlemen enough, so many earlie mushromes, whose best growth sprang from a dunghill, should not aspire to gentilitie. Farewell. Let others liue by begging. Bee thou one of them; practize the art of Wolnor in England to swallow all's giuen thee; and yet let one purgation make thee as hungrie againe as fellowes that worke in saw-pit. Ile go heare the scritch-owle.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: This was Brachiano's Pandar, and 'tis strange
That in such open and apparant guilt
Of his adulterous sister, hee dare vtter
So scandalous a passion. I must wind him.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: How dares this banisht Count returne to Rome,
His pardon not yet purchast? I haue heard
The deceast Dutchesse gaue him pension,
And that he came along from Padua
I'th' traine of the yong Prince. There's somewhat in 't.
Phisitians, that cure poisons, still doe worke
With counterpoisons.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Marke this strange incounter.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: The God of Melancholie turne thy gall to poison,
And let the stigmaticke wrincles in thy face,
Like to the boisterous waues in a rough tide
One still ouertake an other.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I doe thanke thee
And I doe wish ingeniously for thy sake
The dog-daies all yeare long.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: How crokes the rauen?
Is our good Dutchesse dead?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Dead

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O fate!
Misfortune comes like the Crowners businesse,
Huddle vpon huddle.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Shalt thou & I ioyne housekeeping?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Yes, content.
Let's bee vnsociably sociable.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Sit some three daies together, and discourse.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Onely with making faces;
Lie in our clothes.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: With faggots for our pillowes.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And bee lowsie.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: In taffeta lininges; that's gentile melancholie,
Sleepe all day.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Yes: and like your melancholike hare
Feed after midnight.
Wee are obserued: see how yon couple greue.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: What a strange creature is a laughing foole,
As if man were created to no vse
But onely to shew his teeth.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Ile tell thee what,
It would doe well in stead of looking glasses
To set ones face each morning by a sawcer
Of a witches congealed bloud.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Pretious gue.
Weel neuer part.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Neuer: till the beggerie of Courtiers,
The discontent of church-men, want of souldiers,
And all the creatures that hang manacled,
Worse then strappado'd, on the lowest fellie
Of fortunes wheele be taught in our two liues.
To scorne that world which life of meanes depriues.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.l: My Lord, I bring good newes. The Pope on's death-bed,
At th' earnest suit of the great Duke of Florence,
Hath sign'd your pardon, and restor'd vnto you—

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I thanke you for your news. Look vp againe
Flamineo, see my pardon.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Why do you laugh?
There was no such condition in our couenant.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: You shall not seeme a happier man then I,
You know our vow sir, if you will be merry,
Do it i'th like posture, as if some great man
Sate while his enemy were executed:
Though it be very letchery vnto thee,
Doo't with a crabbed Polititians face.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Your sister is a damnable whore.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Ha?
