sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Looke you; I spake that laughing.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Dost euer thinke to speake againe?

sp.speaker: LOD:
sp.l: Do you heare?
Wil't sel me fourty ounces of her bloud,
To water a mandrake?

sp.speaker: FL.
sp.l: Poore Lord; you did vow
To liue a lowzy creature.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Yes;

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Like one
That had for euer forfaited, the day-light,
By being in debt,

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Ha, ha?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: I do not greatly wonder you do breake:
Your Lordship learn't long since. But Ile tell you,

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And't shall sticke by you.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I long for it.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: This laughter scuruily becomes your face,
If you will not be melancholy, be angry.
See now I laugh too.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: You are to blame, Ile force you hence.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Vnhand me:
That ere I should be forc't to right my selfe,
Vpon a Pandar.

sp.speaker: ANT.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: H'had bene as good met with his fist a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: How this shewes!

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Vds' death, how did my sword misse him?
These rogues that are most weary of their liues,
Still scape the greatest dangers,
A pox vpon him: all his reputation;
Nay all the goodnesse of his family;
Is not worth halfe this earthquake.
I learnt it of no fencer to shake thus;
Come, I'le forget him, and go drinke some wine.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Come, come my Lord, vntie your foulded thoughts,
And let them dangle loose as a brid's haire.
Your sister's poisoned.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Farre bee it from my thoughts
To seeke reuenge.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: What, are you turn'd all marble?

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Shall I defye him, and impose a warre
Most burthensome on my poore subiects neckes,
Which at my will I haue not power to end?
You know; for all the murders, rapes, and thefts,
Committed in the horred lust of warre,
He that vniustly caus'd it first proceed,
Shall finde it in his graue and in his seed.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: That's not the course I'de wish you: pray, obserue me,
We see that vndermining more preuailes
Then doth the Canon, Beare your wrongs conceal'd,
And, patient as the Tortoise, let this Cammell
Stalke o're your back vnbruis'd: sleep with the Lyon,
And let this brood of secure foolish mice
Play with your nosthrils, till the time bee ripe
For th'bloudy audit, and the fatall gripe:
Aime like a cunning fowler, close one eie,
That you the better may your game espy.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Free me my innocence; from treacherous actes:
I know ther's thunder yonder: and I'le stand,
Like a safe vallie, which low bends the knee
To some aspiring mountaine: since I know
Treason, like spiders weauing nets for flies,
By her foule worke is found, and in it dies.
To passe away these thoughts, my honour'd Lord,
It is reported you possesse a booke
Wherein you haue quoted, by intelligence,
The names of all notorious offenders
Lurking about the Citty,

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Sir I doe
And some there are which call it my blacke booke:
Well may the title hold: for though it teach not
The Art of coniuring, yet in it lurke,
The names of many deuils.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Pray let's see it.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I'le fetch it to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Monticelso,
I will not trust thee, but in all my plots
I'le rest as iealous as a Towne besieg'd.
Thou canst not reach what I intend to act.
Your flax soone kindles, soone is out againe,
But gold slow heat's, and long will hot remaine.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: 'Tis here my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: First your Intelligencers pray let's see.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Their number rises strangely,
And some of them
You'd Take for honest men.
Next are Pandars.
These are your Pirats: and these following leaues,
For base rogues that vndo yong Gentlemen,
By taking vp commodities: for pollitick bankroupts:
For fellowes that are bawdes to their owne wiues,
Onely to put off horses and slight iewels,
Clockes, defac't plate, and such commodities,
At birth of their first children.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Are there such?

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: These are for Impudent baudes,
That go in mens apparell: for vsurers
That share with scriueners for their good reportage:
For Lawyers that will antedate their writtes:
And some Diuines you might find foulded there;
But that I slip them o're for conscience sake.
Here is a generall catalogue of knaues.
A man might study all the prisons o're,
Yet neuer attaine this knowledge.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Murderers.
Fould downe the leafe I pray,
Good my Lord let me borrow this strange doctrine.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Pray vse't my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I do assure your Lordship,
You are a worthy member of the State,
And haue done infinite good in your discouery
Of these offendors.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Some-what Sir.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: O God!
Better then tribute of wolues paid in England.
'Twill hang their skinnes o'th hedge.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I must make bold
To leaue your Lord-ship.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Deerely sir, I thanke you,
If any aske for me at Court, report
You haue left me in the company of knaues.
I gather now by this, some cunning fellow
That's my Lords Officer, one that lately skipt
From a Clerkes deske vp to a Iustice chaire,
Hath made this knauish summons; and intendes,
As th'Irish rebels wont were to sell heads,
So to make prize of these. And thus it happens,
Your poore rogues pay for't, which haue not the meanes
To present bribe in fist: the rest o'th' band
Are raz'd out of the knaues record; or else
My Lord he winkes at them with easy will,
His man growes rich, the knaues are the knaues still.
But to the vse I'le make of it; it shall serue
To point me out a list of murderers,
Agents for any villany. Did I want
Ten leash of Curtisans, it would furnish me;
Nay lawndresse three Armies. That so in little paper
Should lye th'vndoing of so many men!
'Tis not so big as twenty declarations.
See the corrupted vse some make of bookes:
Diuinity, wrested by some factious bloud,
Draws swords, swels battels, & orethrowes all good.
To fashion my reuenge more seriously,
Let me remember my dead sisters face:
Call for her picture: no; I'le close mine eyes,
And in a melancholicke thought I'le frame
Her figure 'fore me. Now I— ha'te how strong
Imagination workes! how she can frame
Things which are not! me thinks she stands afore me;
And by the quicke Idea of my minde,
Were my skill pregnant, I could draw her picture.
Thought, as a subtile Iugler, makes vs deeme
Things, supernaturall, which haue cause
Common as sickenesse. 'Tis my melancholy,
How cam'st thou by thy death?— how idle am I
To question mine owne idlenesse?— did euer
Man dreame awake till now?— remoue this obiect
Out of my braine with't: what haue I to do
With tombes, or death-beds, funerals, or teares,
That haue to meditate vpon reuenge?
So now 'tis ended, like an old wiues story.
States-men thinke often they see stranger sights
Then mad-men, Come, to this waighty businesse.
My Tragedy must haue some idle mirth in't,
Else it will neuer passe. I am in loue,
In loue with Corombona; and my suite
Thus haltes to her in verse.—
I haue done it rarely: ô the fate of Princes!
I am so vs'd to frequent flattery,
That being alone I now flatter my selfe;
But it will serue, 'tis seal'd; beare this
To th'house of Conuertites; and watch your leisure
To giue it to the hands of Corombona,
Or to the Matron, when some followers
Of Brachiano may be by. Away
He that deales all by strength, his wit is shallow:
When a mans head goes through each limbe will follow.
The engine for my busines, bold Count Lodowicke:
'Tis gold must such an instrument procure,
With empty fist no man doth falcons lure.
Brachiano, I am now fit for thy encounter.
Like the wild Irish I'le nere thinke thee dead,
Till I can play at footeball with thy head.
Flectere sinequeo Superes, Acheronta mouebo.

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.l: Should it be knowne the Duke hath such recourse.
To your imprison'd sister, I were like
T'incur much damage by it.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Not a scruple.
The Pope lies on his death-bed, and their heads
Are troubled now with other businesse
Than guarding of a Ladie.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Yonder's Flamineo in conference
With the Matrona. Let mee speake with you.
I would intreat you to deliuer for mee
This letter to the faire Uittoria.

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: With all care and secrecie,
Hereafter you shall know mee, and receiue
Thankes for this curtesie.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: How now? what's that?

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.l: A letter.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: To my sister: Ile see't deliuered.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: What's that you read Flamineo?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Looke.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Ha? To the most vnfortunate his best respected Uittoria.
Who was the messenger?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: No! Who sent it?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Vd's foot you speake, as if a man
Should know what foule is coffind in a bak't meate
Afore you cut it vp.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Ile open't, were't her heart. What's heere subscribed
This iugling is grosse and palpable. (Florence?
I haue found out the conueyance; read it, read, it.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Your teares Ile turne to triumphes, bee but mine.
Your prop is fall'n; I pittie that a vine
Which Princes heretofore haue long'd to gather,
Wanting suppperters, now should fade and wither.
Wine yfaith, my Lord, with lees would serue his turne.
Your sad imprisonment Ile soone vncharme,
And with a princelie vncontrolled arme
Lead you to Florence, where my loue and care
Shall hang your wishes in my siluer haire.
A halter on his strange aequiuocation.
Nor for my yeares returne mee the sad willow,
Who prefer blossomes before fruit that's mellow.
Rotten on my knowledge with lying too long i'th bed-straw.
And all the lines of age this line conuinces:
The Gods neuer wax old, no more doe Princes.
Apox on't teare it, let's haue no more Atheists for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Vds'death, Ile cut her into Atomies
And let th'irregular North-winde sweepe her vp
And blow her int' his nosthrils. Where's this whore?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: That? what doe you call her?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Oh, I could bee mad,
Preuent the curst disease shee'l bring mee to;
And teare my haire off. Where's this changeable stuffe?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Ore head and eares in water, I assure you,
Shee is not for your wearing.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: In you Pandar?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: What mee, my Lord, am I your dog?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: A bloud-hound: doe you braue? doe you stand mee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Stand you? let those that haue diseases run;
I need no plaisters.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Would you bee kickt?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Would you haue your necke broke?
I tell you Duke, I am not in Russia;
My shinnes must be kept whole.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Do you know mee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O my Lord! methodically.
As in this world there are degrees of euils:
So in this world there are degrees of deuils.
You'r a great Duke; I your poore secretarie.
I doe looke now for a Spanish fig, or an Italian sallet daily.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Pandar, plie your conuoy, and leaue your prating.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: All your kindnesse to mee is like that miserable curtesie of Polyphemus to Ulisses, you reserue mee to be deuour'd last, you would dig turues out of my graue to feed your Larkes: that would bee musicke to you. Come, Ile lead you to her.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Do you face mee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: O Sir I would not go before a Pollitique enemie with my backe towards him, though there were behind mee a whirlepoole.
sp.stage: Enter Vittoria to Brachiano and Flamineo.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Can you read Mistresse? looke vpon that letter;
There are no characters nor Hieroglyphicks.
You need no comment, I am growne your receiuer,
Gods pretious you shall bee a braue great Ladie,
A statelie and aduanced whore.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Say Sir.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Come, come, let's see your Cabinet, discouer
Your treasurie of loue-letters. Death and furies,
Ile see them all.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Sir, vpon my soule,
I haue not any. Whence was this directed?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Confusion on your politicke ignorance.
You are reclaimed; are you? Ile giue you the bels
And let you flie to the deuill.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Ware hawke, my Lord.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Florence! This is some treacherous plot, my Lord,
To mee, he nere was louely I protest,
So much as in my sleepe.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Right: they are plots.
Your beautie! ô, ten thousand curses on't.
How long haue I beheld the deuill in christall?
Thou hast lead mee, like an heathen sacrifice,
With musicke, and with fatal! yokes of flowers
To my eternall ruine. Woman to man
Is either a God or a wolfe.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Away.
Wee'l bee as differing as two Adamants;
The one shall shunne the other. What? do'st weepe?
Procure but ten of thy dissembling trade,
Yee'ld furnish all the Irish funeralls
With howling, past wild Irish.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Fie, my Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: That hand, that cursed hand, which I haue wearied
With doting kisses! O my sweetest Dutchesse
How louelie art thou now! Thy loose thoughtes
Scatter like quicke-siluer, I was bewitch'd;
For all the world speakes ill of thee.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: No matter.
Ile liue so now Ile make that world recant
And change her speeches. You did name your Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Whose death God pardon.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Whose death God reuenge
On thee most godlesse Duke.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Now for tow whirle windes.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: What haue I gain'd by thee but infamie?
Thou hast stain'd the spotlesse honour of my house,
And frighted thence noble societie:
Like those, which sicke 'oth' Palsie, and retaine
Ill-senting foxes 'bout them, are still shun'd
By those of choicer nosthrills. What doe you call this house?
Is this your palace? did not the Iudge stile it
A house of penitent whores? who sent mee to it?
Who hath the honour to aduance Uittoria
To this incontinent colledge? is 't not you?
Is 't not your high preferment? Go, go brag
How many Ladies you haue vndone, like mee.
Fare you well Sir; let me heare no more of you.
I had a limbe corrupted to an vlcer,
But I haue cut it off: and now Ile go
Weeping to heauen on crutches. For your giftes,
I will returne them all; and I do wish
That I could make you full Executor
To all my sinnes, ò that I could tosse my selfe
Into a graue as quickly: for all thou art worth
Ile not shed one teare more;— Ile burst first.
sp.stage: She throwes her selfe vpon a bed.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: I haue drunke Lethe.
Uittoria? My dearest happinesse? Vittoria?
What doe you aile my Loue? why doe you weepe?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Yes, I now weepe poniardes, doe you see.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Are not those matchlesse eies mine?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I had rather.
They were not matches.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Is not this lip mine?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Yes: thus to bite it off, rather than giue it thee.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Turne to my Lord, good sister.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Hence you Pandar.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Pandar! Am I the author of your sinne?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Yes: Hee's a base theif that a theif lets in.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Wee're blowne vp, my Lord,

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Wilt thou heare mee?
Once to bee iealous of thee is t' expresse
That I will loue thee euerlastingly,
And neuer more bee iealous.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O thou foole,
Whose greatnesse hath by much oregrowne thy wit!
What dar'st thou doe, that I not dare to suffer,
Excepting to bee still thy whore? for that;
In the seas bottome sooner thou shalt make
A bonefire.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O, no othes for gods sake.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Will you heare mee?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: What a damn'd impostume is a womans will?
Can nothing breake it? fie, fie, my Lord.
Women are caught as you take Tortoises,
Shee must bee turn'd on her backe. Sister, by this hand
I am on your side. Come, come, you haue wrong'd her.
What a strange credulous man were you, my Lord,
To thinke the Duke of Florence could loue her?
Will any Mercer take an others ware
When once 't is tows'd and sullied? And, yet sister,
How scuruily this frowardnesse becomes you?
Yong Leuerets stand not long; and womens anger
Should, like their flight, procure a little sport;
A full crie for a quarter of an hower;
And then bee put to th' dead quat.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Shall these eies,
Which haue so long time dwelt vpon your face,
Be now put out?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: No cruell Land-ladie 'ith' world,
Which lend's forth grotes to broome-men, & takes vse for them,
Would doe't.
Hand her, my Lord, and kisse her: be not like
A ferret to let go your hold with blowing.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Let vs renew right handes.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Neuer shall rage, or the forgetfull wine,
Make mee commit like fault.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Now you are ith' way out, follow 't hard.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Bee thou at peace with mee; let all the world
Threaten the Cannon.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Marke his penitence.
Best natures doe commit the grossest faultes,
When they're giu'n ore to iealosie; as best wine
Dying makes strongest vinneger. Ile tell you;
The Sea's more rough and raging than calme riuers,
But nor so sweet nor wholesome. A quiet woman
Is a still water vnder a great bridge.
A man may shoot her safely.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O yee dissembling men!

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p:
Wee suckt that, sister, from womens brestes, in our
first infancie.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: To ad miserie to miserie.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Sweetest.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Am I not low enough?
I, I, your good heart gathers like a snow-ball
Now your affection's cold.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Vd'foot, it shall melt,
To a hart againe, or all the wine in Rome
Shall run o'th lees for't.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Your dog or hawke should be rewarded better
Then I haue bin. Ile speake not one word more.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Stop her mouth,
With a sweet kisse, my Lord.
So now the tide's turne'd the vessel's come about
Hee's a sweet armefull. O wee curl'd-haird men
Are still most kind to women. This is well.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: That you should chide thus!

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O, sir, your little chimnies
Doe euer cast most smoke. I swet for you.
Couple together with as deepe a silence,
As did the Grecians in their wodden horse.
My Lord supplie your promises with deedes.
You know that painted meat no hunger feedes.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Stay ingratefull Rome. (vsage.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Rome! it deserues to be cal'd Barbarie, for our villainous

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Soft; the same proiect which the Duke of Florence,
(Whether in loue or gullerie I know not)
Laid downe for her escape, will I pursue.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And no time fitter than this night, my Lord;
The Pope being dead; and all the Cardinals entred
The Conclaue for th' electing a new Pope;
The Cittie in a great confusion;
Wee may attire her in a Pages suit,
Lay her post-horse, take shipping, and amaine
For Padua.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Ile instantly steale forth the Prince Giouanni,
And make for Padua. You two with your old Mother
And yong Marcello that attendes on Florence,
If you can worke him to it, follow mee.
I will aduance you all: for you Vittoria,
Thinke of a Dutchesse title.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Lo you sister.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord; I'le tell you a tale. The crocodile, which liues in the riuer Nilus, hath a worme breds i'th teeth of't, which puts it to extreame anguish: a little bird, no bigger then a wren, is barbor-surgeon to this crocodile; flies into the iawes of't; pickes out the worme; and brings present remedy. The fish, glad of ease but ingratefull to her that did it, that the bird may not talke largely of her abroad for non payment, closeth her chaps intending to swallow her, and so put her to perpetuall silence. But nature loathing such in gratitude, hath arm'd this bird with a quill or pricke on the head, top o'th which wounds the crocodile i'th mouth; forceth her open her bloudy prison; and away flies the pretty tooth-picker from her cruell patient.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: Your application is, I haue not rewarded
The seruice you haue done me.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: No, my Lord;
sp.p: You sister are the crocodile: you are blemisht in your fame, My Lord cures it. And though the comparison hold not in euery particle; yet obserue, remember, what good the bird with the pricke i'th head hath done you; and scorne ingratitude.
sp.l: It may appeare to some ridiculous
Thus to talke knaue and madman; and sometimes
Come in with a dried sentence, stuft with sage.
But this allowes my varying of shapes,
Knaues do grow great by being great mens apes.
sp.stage: Enter Francisco, Lodouico, Gasper, and sixe Embassadours.
At another dore the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: So, my Lord, I commend your diligence
Guard well the conclaue, and, as the order is,
Let none haue conference with the Cardinals.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I shall, my Lord: roome for the Embassadors,

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: They're wondrous braue to day: why do they weare
These seuerall habits?

sp.speaker: LOD,
sp.l: O sir, they'r Knights
Of seuerall Orders.
That Lord i'th blacke cloak with the siluer crosse
Is Knight of Rhodes; the next Knight of S. Michael,
That of the golden fleece; the French-man there
Knight of the Holy-Ghost; my Lord of Sauoy
Knight of th'Annuntiation; the Englishman
Is Knight of th'honoured Garter, dedicated
Vnto their Saint, S. George. I could describe to you
Their seuerall institutions, with the lawes
Annexed to their Orders, but that time
Permits not such discouery.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Where's Count Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: 'Tis o'th point of dinnertime,
Marshall the Cardinals seruice,

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Sir I shall.
sp.stage: Enter seruants with seuerall dishes couered.
sp.l: Stand, let me search your dish, who's this for?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: For my Lord Cardinall Monticelso,

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Whos's this?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: For my Lord Cardinall of Burbon.

sp.speaker: FRE.
sp.l: Why doth he search the dishes, to obserue
What meate is drest?

sp.speaker: ENG.
sp.l: No Sir, but to preuent.
Least any letters should be conuei'd in
To bribe or to sollicite the aduancement
Of any Cardinall, when first they enter
'Tis lawfull for the Embassadours of Princes
To enter with them, and to make their suit
For any man their Prince affecteth best;
But after, till a generall election,
No man may speake with them.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: You that attend on the Lord Cardinals
Open the window, and receiue their viands.

sp.speaker: A CAR.
sp.l: You must returne the seruice; the L. Cardinals
Are busied 'bout electing of the Pope,
They haue giuen o're scrutinie, and are fallen
To admiration.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I'le lay a thousand Duckets you here news
Of a Pope presently, Hearke; sure he's elected,
Behold! my Lord of Arragon appeares,
On the Church battlements.

sp.speaker: ARRAGON.
sp.p: Denuntio vobis gaudium magnum. Reuerendissimus Cardinalis Lorenso de Monticelso electus est in sedem Apostolicam, & elegit sibi nomen Paulum quartum.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.l: Uiuat sanctus Pater Paulus Quartus.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Vittoria my Lord.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Wel: what of her?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Is fled the Citty,

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: With Duke Brachiano.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Fled? Where's the Prince

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Gone with his father. (Giouanni

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Let the Matrona of the Conuertites
Be apprehended: fled ô damnable!
How fortunate are my wishes. Why? 'twas this
I onely laboured. I did send the letter
T'instruct him what to doe. Thy fame, fond Duke,
I first haue poison'd; directed thee the way
To marrie a whore; what can be worse? This followes;
The hand must act to drowne the passionate tongue,
I scorne to weare a sword and prate of wrong.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: My Lord reportes Vittoria Corombona
Is stol'ne from forth the house of Conuertites
By Brachiano, and they're fled the Cittie.
Now, though this bee the first daie of our state,
Wee cannot better please the diuine power,
Than to sequester from the holie Church
These cursed persons. Make it therefore knowne,
Wee doe denounce excommunication
Against them both: all that are theirs in Rome
Wee likewise banish. Set on.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Come deare Lodouico.
You haue tane the sacrament to prosecute
Th' intended murder.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: With all constancie.
But, Sir, I wonder you'l ingage your selfe,
In person, being a great Prince.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Diuert mee not.
Most of his Court are of my faction,
And some are of my councell. Noble freind,
Our danger shall be 'like in this designe,
Giue leaue, part of the glorie may bee mine.
Why did the Duke of Florence with such care
Labour your pardon? say.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Italian beggars will resolue you that
Who, begging of an almes, bid those they beg of
Doe good for their owne sakes; or't may bee
Hee spreades his bountie with a sowing hand,
Like Kinges, who many times giue out of measure;
Not for desert so much as for their pleasure.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: I know you're cunning. Come, what deuill was that
That you were raising?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Deuill, my Lord?
I aske you.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: How doth the Duke imploy you, that his bonnet
Fell with such complement vnto his knee,
When hee departed from you?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Why, my Lord,
Hee told mee of a restie Barbarie horse
Which he would faine haue brought to the carreere,
The 'sault, and the ring galliard. Now, my Lord,
I haue a rare French Rider.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Take you heede:
Least the Iade breake your necke. Doe you put mee off
With your wild horse-trickes? Sirra you doe lie.
O, thou'rt a foule blacke cloud, and thou do'st threat
A violent storme.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Stormes are 'ith aire, my Lord;
I am too low to storme.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: Wretched creature!
I know that thou art fashion'd for all ill,
Like dogges, that once get bloud, they'l euer kill.
About some murder? was't not?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Ile not tell you;
And yet I care not greatly if I doe;
Marry with this preparation. Holie father,
I come not to you as an Intelligencer,
But as a penitent sinner. What I vtter
Is in confession meerely; which you know
Must neuer bee reueal'd.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: You haue oretane mee.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Sir I did loue Brachiano's Dutchesse deerely;
Or rather I pursued her with hot lust,
Though shee nere knew on't. Shee was poyson'd;
Vpon my soule shee was: for which I haue sworne
T'auenge her murder.

sp.speaker: MONT.
sp.l: To the Duke of Florence?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: To him I haue.

sp.speaker: MON.
sp.l: Miserable Creature!
If thou persist in this, 'tis damnable.
Do'st thou imagine thou canst slide on bloud
And not be tainted with a shamefull fall?
Or like the blacke, and melancholicke Eugh-tree,
Do'st thinke to roote thy selfe in dead mens graues,
And yet to prosper? Instruction to thee
Comes like sweet shewers to ouer-hardned ground:
They wet, but peirce not deepe. And so I leaue thee
With all the Furies hanging bout thy necke,
Till by thy penitence thou remoue this euill,
In coniuring from thy breast that cruell Deuill.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: I'le giue it o're. He saies 'tis damable:
Besides I did expect his suffrage,
By reason of Camillo's death.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Do you know that Count?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, & Francisco,

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Beare him these thousand Duckets to his lodging;
Tell him the Pope hath sent them. Happily
That will confirme more then all the rest.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: To me sir?

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.l: His holinesse hath sent you a thousand Crownes,
And will you if you trauaile, to make him (commanded.
Your Patron for intelligence.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: His creature euer to bee
Why now 'tis come about. He rai'ld vpon me;
And yet these Crownes were told out and laid ready,
Before he knew my voiage. O the Art
The modest forme of greatnesse! that do sit
Like Brides at wedding dinners, with their look's turn'd
From the least wanton iests, their puling stomacke
Sicke of the modesty, when their thoughts are loose.
Euen acting of those hot and lustfull sports
Are to ensue about midnight: such his cunning!
Hee soundes my depth thus with a golden plummet,
I am doubly arm'd now. Now to th'act of bloud,
There's but three furies found in spacious hell;
But in a great mans breast three thousand dwell.
sp.stage: A passage ouer the stage of Brachiano, Flamineo, Marcello, Hortensio, Corombona, Cornelia, Zanche and others.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: In all the weary minutes of my life,
Day nere broke vp till now. This mariage.
Confirmes me happy.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: 'Tis a good assurance.
Saw you not yet the Moore that's come to Court?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Yes, and confer'd with him i'th Dukes closet,
I haue not seene a goodlier personage,
Nor euer talkt with man better experienc't
In State-affares or rudiments of warre.
Hee hath by report, seru'd the Venetian
In Candy these twice seuen yeares, and bene cheife
In many a bold designe.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: What are those two,
That beare him company?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Two Noblemen of Hungary, that liuing in the Emperours seruice as commanders, eight yeares since, contrary to the expectation of all the Court entred into religion, into the strickt order of Capuchins: but being not well setled in their vndertaking they left their Order and returned to Court: for which being after troubled in conscience, they vowed their seruice against the enemies of Christ; went to Malta; were there knighted; and in their returne backe, at this great solemnity, they are resolued for euer to forsake the world, and settle themselues here in a house of Capuchines in Padua.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: One thing makes it so. They haue vowed for euer to weare next their bare bodies those coates of maile they serued in.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Hard penance.
Is the Moore a Christian?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Hee is.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Why proffers hee his seruice to our Duke?

sp.speaker: FLV.
sp.l: Because he vnderstands ther's like to grow
Some warres betweene vs and the Duke of Florence,
In which hee hopes imployment.
I neuer saw one in a sterne bold looke
Weare more command, nor in a lofty phrase
Expresse more knowing, or more deepe contempt
Of our slight airy Courtiers. Hee talkes
As if hee had trauail'd all the Princes Courts
Of Christendome; in all things striues t'expresse,
That all that should dispute with him may know,
Glories, like glow-wormes, a farre off shine bright
But lookt to neare, haue neither heat nor light.
The Duke.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, Florence disguised like Mulinassar; Lodouico, Antonelli, Gaspar, Farnese bearing their swordes and helmets.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: You'are nobly welcome. Wee haue heard at full
Your honourable seruice 'gainst the Turke.
To you, braue Mulinassar, wee assigne
A competent pension: and are inly sorrow,
The vowes of those two worthie gentlemen,
Make them incapable of our proffer'd bountie.
Your wish is you may leaue your warlike swordes
For Monuments i in our Chappell. I accept it
As a great honour done mee, and must craue
Your leaue to furnish out our Dutchesse reuells.
Onely one thing, as the last vanitie
You ere shall view, denie mee not to stay
To see a Barriers prepar'd to night;
You shall haue priuate standings: It hath pleas'd
The great Ambassadours of seuerall Princes
In their returne from Rome to their owne Countries
To grace our marriage, and to honour mee
With such a kind of sport.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I shall perswade them
To stay, my Lord.
Set on there to the presence

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.l: Noble my Lord, most fortunately wellcome,
You haue our vowes seal'd with the sacrament
To second your attempts.

sp.speaker: PED.
sp.l: And all thinges readie.
Hee could not haue inuented his owne ruine,
Had hee despair'd with more proprietie.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: You would not take my way.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: 'Tis better ordered.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: 'T'haue poison'd his praier booke, or a paire of beades,
The pummell of his saddle, his looking-glasse,
Or th'handle of his racket, ô that, that!
That while he had bin bandying at Tennis,
He might haue sworne himselfe to hell, and strooke
His soule into the hazzard! O my Lord!
I would haue our plot bee ingenious,
And haue it hereafter recorded for example
Rather than borrow example.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: There's no way
More speeding than this thought on.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: On then.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: And yet mee thinkes that this reuenge is poore,
Because it steales vpon him like a theif,
To haue tane him by the Caske in a pitcht feild,
Led him to Florence!

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: It had bin rare.— And there
Haue crown'd him with a wreath of stinking garlicke.
T'haue showne the sharpnesse of his gouernment;
And rancknesse of his lust.
Flamineo comes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Why doth this deuill haunt you? say.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I know not.
For by this light I doe not coniure for her.
Tis not so great a cunning as men thinke
To raise the deuill: for heeres one vp allreadie,
The greatest cunning were to lay him downe

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Shee is your shame.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I prethee pardon her.
In faith you see, women are like to burres;
Where their affection throwes them, there they'l sticke.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: That is my Country-man, a goodly person;
When hee's at leisure Ile discourse with him
In our owne language.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I beseech you doe,
How is 't' braue souldier; ô that I had seene
Some of your iron daies! I pray relate
Some of your seruice to vs.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.p: T'is a ridiculous thing for a man to bee his owne Chronicle, I did neuer wash my mouth with mine owne praise for feare of getting a stincking breath.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You're too Stoicall. The Duke will expect other discourse from you

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.p:
I shall neuer flatter him, I haue studied man to much to do that: What difference is betweene the Duke and I? no more than betweene two brickes; all made of one clay. Onely't may bee one is plac't on the top of a turret; the other in the bottom of a well by meere chance; if I were plac't as high as the Duke, I should sticke as fast; make as faire a shew; and beare out
weather equally.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: If this souldier had a patent to beg in Churches, then hee would tell them stories,

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: I haue bin a souldier too.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: How haue you thriu'd?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Faith poorely.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.p: That's the miserie of peace. Onely outsides are then respected: As shippes seeme verie great vpon the riuer, which shew verie little vpon the Seas: So some men i'th Court seeme Colossusses in a chamber, who if they came into the feild would appeare pittifull. Pigmies.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Giue mee a faire roome yet hung with Arras, and some great Cardinall to lug mee by th' eares as his endeared Minion.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: And thou maist doe, the deuill knowes what vilanie.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And safely.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.p: Right; you shall see in the Countrie in haruest time, pigeons, though they destroy neuer so much corne, the farmer dare not present the fowling peece to them! why? because they belong to the Lord of the Mannor; whilest your poore sparrowes that belong to the Lord of heauen, they go to the pot for't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I will now giue you some polliticke instruction. The Duke saies hee will giue you pension; that's but bare promise: get it vnder his hand. For I haue knowne men that haue come from seruing against the Turke; for three or foure moneths they haue had pension to buy them new woodden legges and fresh plaisters; but after 'twas not to bee had. And this miserable curtesie shewes, as if a Tormenter should giue hot cordiall drinkes to one three quarters dead o'th' racke, onely to fetch the miserable soule againe to indure more dogdaies.
sp.stage: Enter Hortensio, a yong Lord, Zanche, and two more.
sp.l: How now, Gallants; what are they readie for the Barriers?

sp.speaker: Y. LORD.
sp.l: Yes: the Lordes are putting on their armour.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: What's hee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: A new vp-start: one that sweares like a Falckner, and will lye in the Dukes eare day by day like a maker of Almanacks; And yet I knew him since hee came to th' Court smell worse of sweat than an vnder-tennis-court keeper.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Looke you, yonder's your sweet Mistresse.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Thou art my sworne brother, I'le tell thee, I doe loue that Moore, that Witch very constrainedly: shee knowes some of my villanny; I do loue her, iust as a man holds a wolfe by the eares. But for feare of turning vpon mee, and pulling out my throate, I would let her go to the Deuill.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: I heare she claimes marriage of thee.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: 'Faith, I made to her some such darke promise, and in seeking to flye from't I run on, like a frighted dog with a bottle at 's taile, that faine would bite it off and yet dares not looke behind him. Now my pretious Gipsie!

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: I your loue to me rather cooles then heates.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Marry, I am the sounder, louer, we haue many wenches about the Towne heate too fast.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: What do you thinke of these perfum'd Gallants then?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Their sattin cannot saue them. I am confident
They haue a certaine spice of the disease,
For they that sleep with dogs; shall rise with fleas.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Beleeue it! A little painting and gay clothes,
Make you loath me.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: How? loue a Lady for painting or gay apparell? I'le vnkennell one example more for thee. Esop had a foolish dog that let go the flesh to catch the shadow. I would haue Courtiers bee better Diuers.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: You remember your oathes.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Louers oathes are like Marriners prayers, vttered in extremity; but when the tempest is o're, and that the vessell leaues tumbling, they fall from protesting to drinking. And yet amongst Gentlemen protesting and drinking go together, and agree as well as Shooemakers and West-phalia bacon. They are both drawers on: for drinke drawes on protestation; and protestation drawes on more drinke. Is not this discourse better now then the mortality of your sun-burnt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Is this your pearch, you haggard? flye to'th stewes.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: You should be clapt by th'heeles now: strike i'th Court.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: She's good for nothing but to make her maids,
Catch cold a nights; they dare not vse a bedstaffe,
For feare of her light fingers.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Your'e a strumpet.
An impudent one.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Why do you kicke her? say,
Do you thinke that she's like a walnut-tree?
Must she be cudgel'd ere shee beare good fruite?
Shee brags that you shall marry her.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: I had rather she were pitcht vpon a stake
In some new-seeded garden, to affright
Her fellow crowes thence.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Your a boy, a foole,
Be guardian to your hound, I am of age.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: If I take her neere you I'le cut her throate.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: With a fan of feathers?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: And for you; I'le whip
This folly from you.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: Are you cholericke?
I'le purg't with Rubarbe.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: O your brother.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Hang him.
Hee wrongs me most that ought t'offend mee least,
I do suspect my mother plaid soule play,
When she conceiu'd thee.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Now by all my hopes.
Like the two slaughtred sonnes of Oedipus,
The very flames of our affection,
Shall turne 10 waies. Those words I'le make thee answere
With thy heart bloud.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Doe like the geesse in the progresse,
You know where you shall finde mee,

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Very good,
And thou beest a noble, friend, beare him my sword,
And bid him fit the length on't.

sp.speaker: Y. LORD.
sp.l: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: He comes. Hence petty thought of my disgrace,
I neere lou'd my complexion till now,
sp.stage: Enter Francisco the Duke of Florence.
sp.l: Cause I may boldly say without a blush,
I loue you.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Your loue is vntimely sowen,
Ther's a Spring at Michaelmas, but 'tis but a faint one, I am sunck
In yeares, and I haue vowed neuer to marry.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Alas! poore maides get more louers then husbands,
sp.p: Yet you may mistake my wealth. For, as when Embassadours are sent to congratulate Princes, there's commonly sent along with them a rich present; so that though the Prince like not the Embassadours person nor words, yet he likes well of the presentment. So I may come to you in the same maner, & be better loued for my dowry then my vertue.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I'le thinke on the motion.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.p: Do, Ile now detaine you no longer. At your better leasure I'le tell you things shall startle your bloud.
sp.l: Nor blame me that this passion I reueale;
Louers dye inward that their flames conceale.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Of all intelligence this may proue the best,
Sure I shall draw strange fowle, from this foule nest.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: I heare a whispering all about the Court,
You are to fight, who is your opposite?
What is the quarrell?

sp.speaker: MRA.
sp.l: 'Tis an idle rumour.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Will you dissemble? sure you do not well
To fright me thus, you neuer look thus pale,
But when you are most angry. I do charge you
Vpon my blessing; nay I'le call the Duke,
And he shall schoole you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: Publish not a feare
Which would conuert to laughter; 'tis not so,
Was not this Crucifix my fathers?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: I haue heard you say, giuing my brother sucke,
Hee tooke the Crucifix betweene his hands,
And broke a limbe off.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Yes: but 'tis mended.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I haue brought your weapon backe.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Ha, O my horrour!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: You haue brought it home indeed.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Helpe, oh he's murdered.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Do you turne your gaule vp? I'le to sanctuary,
And send a surgeon to you.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: How? o'th ground?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.l: O mother now remember what I told,
Of breaking off the Crucifix: farewell
There are some sinnes which heauen doth duly punish,
In a whole family. This it is to rise
By all dishonest meanes. Let all men know
That tree shall long time keepe a steddy foote
Whose branches spread no wilder then the roote.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O my perpetuall sorrow!

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Vertuous Marcello.
Hee's dead: pray leaue him Lady; come, you shall.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Alas he is not dead: hee's in a trance.
sp.p: Why here's no body shall get any thing by his death. Let me call him againe for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: CAR.
sp.l: I would you were deceiu'd.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p:
O you abuse mee, you abuse me, you abuse me. How many haue gone away thus for lacke of tendance; reare vp's head,
reare vp's head; His bleeding inward will kill him.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: You see hee is departed.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Let mee come to him; giue mee him as hee is, if hee bee turn'd to earth; let mee but giue him one heartie kisse, and you shall put vs both into one coffin: fetch a looking glasse, see if his breath will not staine it; or pull out some feathers from my pillow, and lay them to his lippes, will you loose him for a little paines taking?

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Your kindest office is to pray for him.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Alas! I would not pray for him yet. Hee may liue to lay mee ith' ground, and pray for mee, if you'l let mee come to him.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano all armed, saue the beauer, with Flamineo.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Was this your handy-worke?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: It was my misfortune.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.p: Hee lies, hee lies, hee did not kill him: these haue kill'd him, that would not let him bee better look't to.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Haue comfort my greiu'd Mother.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O you scritch-owle.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: Forbeare, good Madam.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Let mee goe, let mee goe.
sp.stage: Shee runes to Flamineo with her knif drawne and comming to him lets it fall.
sp.l: The God of heauen forgiue thee. Do'st not wonder
I pray for thee? Ile tell thee what's the reason,
I haue scarce breath to number twentie minutes;
Ide not spend that in cursing. Fare thee well
Halfe of thy selfe lies there: and maist thou liue
To fill an howre-glasse with his mouldred ashes,
To tell how thou shouldst spend the time to come
In blest repentance.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Mother, pray tell mee
How came hee by his death? what was the quarrell?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Indeed my yonger boy presum'd too much
Vpon his manhood; gaue him bitter wordes;
Drew his sword first; and so I know not how,
For I was out of my wits, hee fell with's head
Iust in my bosome.

sp.speaker: PAGE.
sp.l: This is not trew Madam.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: I pray thee peace.
One arrow's graz'd allready; it were vaine
T'lose this: for that will nere bee found againe.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Go, beare the bodie to Corneliá; lodging:
And wee commaund that none acquaint our Dutchesse:
With this sad accident: for you Flamineo,
Hearke you, I will not graunt your pardon.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Onely a lease of your life. And that shall last
sp.p: But for one day. Thou shalt be forc't each euening to renew it, or be hang'd.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: At your pleasure.
sp.stage: Lodouico sprinckles Brachiano's beuer with a poison.
sp.l: Your will is law now, Ile not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: You once did braue mee in your sisters lodging;
I'le now keepe you in awe for't. Where's our beauer?

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Hee cals for his destruction. Noble youth,
I pitty thy sad fate. Now to the barriers.
This shall his passage to the blacke lake further,
The last good deed hee did, he pardon'd murther.
sp.stage: Charges and shoutes, They fight at Barriers; first single paires, then three to three.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: An Armorer? vds death an Armorer?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Armorer; where's the Armorer?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Teare off my beauer.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Are you hurt, my Lord?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: O my braine's on fire,
The helmet is poison'd.

sp.speaker: ARM.
sp.l: My Lord vpon my soule.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Away with him to torture.
There are some great ones that haue hand in this,
And neere about me.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O my loued Lord, poisoned?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Remoue the barre: heer's vnfortunate reuls,
Call the Physitions; a plague vpon you;
Wee haue to much of your cunning here already.
I feare the Embassadours are likewise poyson'd.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Oh I am gone already: the infection
Flies to the braine and heart. O thou strong heart!
There's such a couenant 'tweene the world and it,
They're loath to breake.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: O my most loued father!

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Remoue the boy away,
Where's this good woman? had I infinite worlds
They were too little for thee. Must I leaue thee?
What say you scritch-owles, is the venomne mortall?

sp.speaker: PHYS.
sp.l: Most deadly.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Most corrupted pollitick hangman!
You kill without booke; but your art to saue
Failes you as oft, as great mens needy friends.
I that haue giuen life to offending slaues
And wretched murderers, haue I not power
To lengthen mine owne a twelue-month?
Do not kisse me, for I shall poyson thee.
This vnction is sent from the great Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Sir bee of comforts

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: O thou soft naturall death, that art ioint-twin,
To sweetest slumber: no rough-bearded Comet,
Stares on thy milde departure: the dull Owle
Beates not against thy casement: the hoarse wolfe
Sents not thy carion. Pitty windes thy coarse,
Whilst horrour waights on Princes.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I am lost for euer.

sp.speaker: BRAC.
sp.l: How miserable a thing it is to die,
'Mongst women howling! What are those.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Franciscant.
They haue brought the extreame vnction.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: On paine of death, let no man name death to me,
It is a word infinitely terrible,
Withdraw into our Cabinet

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: To see what solitarinesse is about dying Princes. As heretofore they haue vnpeopled Townes; diuorst friends, and made great houses vnhospitable: so now, ô iustice! where are their flatterers now? Flatterers are but the shadowes of Princes bodies the least thicke cloud makes them inuisible.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: There's great moane made for him.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: 'Faith, for some few howers salt water will runne most plentifully in euery Office o'th Court. But beleeue it; most of them do but weepe ouer their step-mothers graues.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How meane you?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Why? They dissemble, as some men doe that liue within compasse o'th verge.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Come you haue thriu'd well vnder him.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: 'Faith, like a wolfe in a womans breast; I haue beene fed with poultry; but for money, vnderstand me, I had as good a will to cosen him, as e're an Officer of them all. But I had not cunning enough to doe it.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: What did'st thou thinke of him; 'faith speake freely.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Hee was a kinde of States-man, that would sooner haue reckond how many Cannon bullets he had discharged against a Towne, to count his expence that way, than how many of his valiant and deseruing subiects hee lost before it.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: O, speake well of the Duke.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I haue done.
Will't heare some of my Court wisedome?
To reprehend Princes is dangerous: and to ouer-commend some
of them is palpable lying.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: How is it with the Duke?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Most deadly ill.
Hee's fall'n into a strange distraction.
Hee talkes of Battailes and Monopolies,
Leuying of taxes, and from that descends
To the most brain-sicke language. His minde fastens
On twentie seuerall obiects, which confound
Deepe Sence with follie. Such a fearefull end
May teach some men that beare too loftie crest,
Though they liue happiest, yet they dye not best.
Hee hath conferr'd the whole State of the Dukedome
Vpon your sister, till the Prince arriue
At mature age.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: There's some good lucke in that yet.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: See heere he comes.
sp.stage: Enter Brachiano, presented in a bed Uittoria and others.
sp.l: There's death in's face allready.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O my good Lord!

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Away, you haue abus'd mee.
You haue conuayd coyne forth our territories;
Bought and sold offices; oppres'd the poore,
sp.stage: These speches are seuerall kinds of distractions and in the action should appeare so.
sp.l: And I nere dreampt on't. Make vp your accountes;
Ile now bee mine owne Steward.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Sir, haue patience.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Indeed I am too blame.
For did you euer heare the duskie rauen
Chide blacknesse? or wast euer knowne, the diuell
Raild against clouen Creatures.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O my Lord!

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Let mee haue some quailes to supper.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Sir, you shal.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: No: some fried dog-fish. Your Quailes feed on poison,
That old dog-fox, that Polititian Florence,
Ile forsweare hunting and turne dog-killer;
Rare! Ile bee frindes with him. for marke you, sir, one dog
Still sets another a barking: peace, peace,
Yonder's a fine slaue come in now.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Why there.
In a blew bonnet, and a paire of breeches
With a great codpeece. Ha, ha, ha,
Looke you his codpeece is stucke full of pinnes
With pearles o'th head of them. Doe not you know him?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Why 'tis the Deuill.
I know him by a great rose he weares on's shooe
To hide his clouen foot. Ile dispute with him.
Hee's a rare linguist.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: My Lord heer's nothing.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Nothing? rare! nothing! when I want monie,
Our treasurie is emptie; there is nothing,
Ile not bee vs'd thus.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O! 'ly still, my Lord

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: See, see, Flamineo that kill'd his brother
Is dancing on the ropes there: and he carries
A monie-bag in each hand, to keepe him euen,
For feare of breaking's necke. And there's a Lawyer
In a gowne whipt with veluet, stares and gapes
When the mony will fall. How the rogue cuts capers!
It should haue bin in a halter.
'Tis there; what's shee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Uittoria, my Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Her haire is sprinckled with Arras powder, that makes her looke as if she had sinn'd in the Pastrie. What's hee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: A Diuine my Lord.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.p: Hee will bee drunke: Auoid him: th' argument is fearefull when Church-men stagger in't.
sp.stage: Brachiano seemes heare neare his end. Lodouico & Gasparo in the habit of Capuchins present him in his bed with a Crucifix and hallowed candle.
sp.p: Looke you; six gray rats that haue lost their tailes, crall vp the pillow, send for a Rat-cather.
Ile doe a miracle: Ile free the Court
From all foule vermin. Where's Flamineo?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I doe not like that hee names mee so often,
Especially on's death-bed: 'tis a signe
I shall not liue long: see hee's neere his end.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Pray giue vs leaue; Attende Domine Brachiane,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: See, see, how firmely hee doth fixe his eye
Vpon the Crucifix.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O hold it constant.
It settles his wild spirits; and so his eies
Melt into teares.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.p: Domine Brachiane, solebas in bello tutus esse tuo clypeo, nùnc hunc clypeum hostituo opponas infernali.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.p: Olim hasta valuisti in bello; nùnc hanc sacram hastam vibrabis contra hostem animarum.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.p: Attende Domine Brachiane si nunc quòque probas ea quae acta sunt inter nos, flecte Caput in dextrum.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.p: Esto securus Domine Brachiane: cogita quantum habeas meritorum denique memineris meam animam pro tua oppignoratem si quid esset periculi.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.p: Si nùnc quoque probas ea quae acta sunt inter nos, flecte caput in leuum.
sp.l: Hee is departing: pray stand all apart,
And let vs onely whisper in his eares
Some priuate meditations, which our order
sp.stage: Heare therest being departed Lodouico and Gasparo discouer themselues.
sp.l: Permits you not to heare.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Brachiano.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Deuill Brachiano.
Thou art damn'd.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Perpetually.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: A slaue condemn'd, and giuen vp to the gallowes
Is thy great Lord and Master.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: True: for thou
Art giuen vp to the deuill.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: O you slaue!
You that were held the famous Pollititian;
Whose art was poison.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: And whose conscience murder.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.p: That would haue broke your wiues necke downe the staires ere she was poison'd.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: That had your villanous

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: And fine imbrodered bottles, (sallets
And perfumes
Equally mortall with a winter plague

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Now there's Mercarie.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: And copperesse

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: And quicke-siluer.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: With other deuelish potticarie stuffe
A melting in your polliticke braines: do'st heare.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: This is Count Lodouico.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: This Gasparo.
And thou shalt die like a poore rogue.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: And stinke
Like a dead flie-blowne dog.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: And be forgotten before thy funerall sermon.

sp.speaker: BRA.
sp.l: Uittoria? Uittoria!

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: O the cursed deuill,
Come to himselfe a gaine. Wee are vndone.
(againe

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: Strangle him in priuate. What? will you call him
To liue in treble torments? for charitie,
For Christian charitie, auoid the chamber.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: You would prate, Sir. This is a true-loue knot
Sent from the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: What is it done?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: The snuffe is out. No woman-keeper i'ch world,
Though shee had practis'd seuen yere at the Pest-house,
Could haue done't quaintlyer. My Lordes hee's dead.

sp.speaker: OMN.
sp.l: Rest to his soule.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O mee! this place is hell.

sp.speaker: FLO.
sp.l: How heauily shee takes it.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O yes, yes;
Had women nauigable riuers in their eies
They would dispend them all; surely I wonder
Why wee should wish more riuers to the Cittie,
When they sell water so good cheape. Ile tell thee,
These are but Moonish shades of greifes or feares,
There's nothing sooner drie than womens-teares.
Why heere's an end of all my haruest, hee has giuen mee nothing
Court promises! Let wisemen count them curst
For while you liue hee that scores best paies worst.

sp.speaker: FLO.
sp.l: Sure, this was Florence doing.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Very likelie.
Those are found waightie strokes which come from th'hand,
But those are killing strokes which come from th'head.
O the rare trickes of a Machiuillian!
Hee doth not come like a grosse plodding slaue
And buffet you to death: No, my quaint knaue,
Hee tickles you to death; makes you die laughing;
As if you had swallow'd downe a pound of saffron
You see the seat, 'tis practis'd in a trice
To teach Court-honestie, it iumpes on Ice.

sp.speaker: FLO.
sp.l: Now haue the people libertie to talke
And descant on his vices.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Miserie of Princes,
That must of force bee censur'd by their slaues!
Not onely blam'd for doing things are ill,
But for not doing all that all men will.
One were better be a thresher.
Vds'death, I would faine speake with this Duke yet.

sp.speaker: FLO.
sp.l: Now hee's dead?

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.l: I cannot coniure; but if praiers or oathes
Will get to th'speech of him: though forty deuils
Waight on him in his liuery of flames,
I'le speake to him, and shake him by the hand,
Though I bee blasted.

sp.speaker: FRA
sp.l: Excellent Lodouico!
What? did you terrifie him at the last gaspe?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Yes; and so idely, that the Duke had like
T'haue terrified vs.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: You shall heare that heareafter,
See! yon's the infernall, that would make vp sport.
Now to the reuelation of that secret,
Shee promi'st when she fell in loue with you.

sp.speaker: FLO.
sp.l: You're passionately met in this sad world.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: I would haue you look vp, Sir; these Court teares
Claime not your tribute to them. Let those weepe
That guiltily pertake in the sad cause.
I knew last night by a sad dreame I had
Some mischiefe would insue; yet to say truth
My dreame most concern'd you.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Shal's fall a dreaming?

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Yes, and for fashion sake Ile dreame with her.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Mee thought sir, you came stealing to my bed.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Wilt thou beleeue me sweeting; by this light
I was a dreampt on thee too: for me thought
I saw thee naked

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Fy sir! as I told you,
Me thought you lay downe by me.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: So drempt I;
And least thou should'st take cold, I couer'd thee
With this Irish mantle.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Verily I did dreame,
You were some what bold with me; but to come to't.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: How? how? I hope you will not go to there.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Nay: you must heare my dreame out.

sp.speaker: MOORE.
sp.l: Well, sir, forth.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: When I threw the mantle ore thee, thou didst laugh
Exceedingly me thought.

sp.speaker: MOORE.
sp.l: Laugh?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: And cridst out,
The haire did tickle thee.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: There was a dreame indeed.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Marke her I prethee, shee simpers like the suddes
A Collier hath bene washt in.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Come, sir; good fortune tends you; I did tell you
I would reueale a secret, Isabella
The Duke of Florence sister was impoison'd,
By a 'fum'd picture: and Camillo's necke
Was broke by damn'd Flamineo; the mischance
Laid on a vaulting horse.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Most strange!

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: The bed of snakes is broke.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: I sadly do confesse I had a hand
In the blacke deed.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Thou kepts their counsell,

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Right,
For which, vrg'd with contrition, I intend
This night to rob Vittoria.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Excellent penitence!
Vsurers dreame on't while they sleepe out Sermons.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: To further our escape, I haue entreated
Leaue to retire me, till the funerall,
Vnto a friend i'th country. That excuse
Will further our escape, In coine and iewels
I shall, at least, make good vnto your vse
An hundred thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: O noble wench!

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Those crownes we'le share.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: It is a dowry,
Me thinkes, should make that sun-burnt prouerbe false,
And wash the Ethiop white.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: It shall, away

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Be ready for our flight.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: An howre 'fore day.
O strange discouery! why till now we knew not
The circumstance of either of their deaths.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: You'le waight about midnight
In the Chappel.

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: Why now our action's iustified,

sp.speaker: FRA.
sp.l: Tush for iustice.
What harmes it Iustice? we now, like the partridge
Purge the disease with lawrell: for the fame
Shall crowne the enterprise and quit the shame.
sp.stage: Enter Flam. and Gasp. at one dore, another way Giouanni attended.

sp.speaker: GAS.
sp.l: The yong Duke: Did you e're see a sweeter Prince?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I haue knowne a poore womans bastard better fauor'd, This is behind him: Now, to his face all comparisons were hateful: Wise was the Courtly Peacocke, that being a great Minion, and being compar'd for beauty, by some dottrels that stood by, to the Kingly Eagle, said the Eagle was a farre fairer bird then herselfe, not in respect of her feathers, but in respect of her long Tallants. His will grow out in time,
My gratious Lord.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: I pray leaue mee Sir.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Your Grace must be merry: 'tis I haue cause to mourne, for wot you what said the little boy that rode behind his father on horsebacke?

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Why, what said hee?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: When you are dead father (said he) I hope then I shall ride in the saddle, O 'tis a braue thing for a man to sit by himselfe: he may stretch himselfe in the stirrops, looke about, and see the whole compasse of the Hemisphere, you're now, my Lord, ith saddle.

sp.speaker: GIO.
sp.l: Study your praiers, sir, and be penitent,
'Twere fit you'd thinke on what hath former bin,
I haue heard griefe nam'd the eldest child of sinne.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Study my praiers? he threatens me diuinely,
I am falling to peeces already, I care not, though, like Anacharsis
sp.p: I were pounded to death in a mortar. And yet that death were fitter for Vsurers gold and themselues to be beaten together, to make a most cordiall cullice for the deuill.
sp.l: He hath his vnckles villanous looke already,
In dicimo sexto. Now sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: COVR
sp.l: It is the pleasure sir, of the yong Duke
That you forbeare the Presence, and all roome,
That owe him reuerence.

sp.speaker: FLAM.
sp.p: So, the wolfe and the rauen are very pretty fools when they are yong. Is it your office, sir, to keepe me out?

sp.speaker: COVR.
sp.l: So the Duke wils.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p:
Verely, Maister Courtier, extreamity is not to bee vsed
in all offices: Say that a gentlewoman were taken out of her bed about midnight, and committed to Castle Angelo, to the Tower yonder, with nothing about her, but her smocke: would it not shew a cruell part in the gentleman porter to lay clame to her vpper garment, pull it ore her head and eares; and put her in nak'd?

sp.speaker: COVR.
sp.l: Very good: you are merrie

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Doth hee make a Court eiectment of mee? A flaming firebrand casts more smoke without a chimney, then withint. Ile smoore some of them.
sp.l: How now? Thou hart sad.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: I met euen now with the most pitious sight.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Thou metst another heare a pittifull
Degraded Courtier.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Your reuerend mother
Is growne a very old woman in two howers.
I found them winding of Marcello's coarse;
And there is such a solemne melodie
'Tweene dolefull songes, teares, and sad elegies:
Such, as old grandames, watching by the dead,
Were wont t'out-weare the nights with; that beleeue mee
I had no eies to guide mee forth the roome,
They were so ore-charg'd with water.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I will see them.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: 'Twere much vncharety in you: for your sight
Will adde vnto their teares.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I will see them.
They are behind the trauers. Ile discouer
Their superstitious howling.
sp.stage: Cornelia, the Moore and 3. other Ladies discouered, winding Marcello's Coarse. A song.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: This rosemarie is wither'd, pray get fresh;
I would haue these herbes grow vp in his graue
When I am dead and rotten. Reach the bayes,
Ile tye a garland heere about his head:
'Twill keepe my boy from lightning. This sheet
I haue kept this twentie yere, and euerie daie
Hallow'd it with my praiers, I did not thinke
Hee should haue wore it.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Looke you; who are yonder.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: O reach mee the flowers.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: Her Ladiships foolish.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: Alas! her grief
Hath turn'd her child againe.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: You're very wellcome.
There's Rosemarie for you, and Rue for you,
Hearts-ease for you. I pray make much of it.
I haue left more for my selfe.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Ladie, who's this?

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: You are, I take it, the graue-maker.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: MOO.
sp.l: 'Tis Flamineo.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Will you make mee such a foole? heere's a white hand:
Can bloud so soone bee washt out? Let mee see,
When scritch-howles croke vpon the chimney tops,
And the strange Cricket ith ouen singes and hoppes,
When yellow spots doe on your handes appeare,
Bee certaine then you of a Course shall heare.
Out vpon't, how 'tis speckled! h'as handled a toad sure.
Couslep-water is good for the memorie: pray buy mee 3. ounces of't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I would I were from hence.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Do you heere,
Ile giue you a saying which my grandmother (sir?
Was wont, when she heard the bell tolle, to sing ore vnto her lute

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Doe and you will, doe.

sp.speaker: COR.
sp.l: Call for the Robin-Red-brest and the wren,
Since ore shadie groues they houer,
sp.stage: Cornelia doth this in seuerall formes of distraction.
sp.l: And with leaues and flowres doe couer
The friendlesse bodies of vnburied men.
Call vnto his funerall Dole
The Ante, the field-mouse, and the mole
To reare him hillockes, that shall keepe him warme,
And (when gay tombes are rob'd) sustaine no harme,
But keepe the wolfe far thence: that's foe to men,
For with his nailes hee'l dig them vp agen.
They would not bury him 'cause hee died in a quarrell
But I haue an answere for them.
Let holie Church receiue him duly
Since hee payd the Church tithes truly.
His wealth is sum'd, and this is all his store:
This poore men get; and great men get no more.
Now the wares are gone, wee may shut vp shop.
Blesse you all good people,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I haue a strange thing in mee, to th' which
I cannot giue a name, without it bee
Compassion, I pray leaue mee.
This night Ile know the vtmost most of my fate,
Ile bee resolu'd what my rich sister meanes
T'assigne mee for my seruice: I haue liu'd
Riotously ill, like some that liue in Court.
And sometimes, when my face was full of smiles,
Haue felt the mase of conscience in my brest.
Oft gay and honour'd robes those tortures trie,
"Wee thinke cag'd birds sing, when indeed they crie.
Ha! I can stand thee. Neerer, neerer yet.
sp.stage: In his leather Cassock & breeches bootes, a coot a pot of lilly flowers with a scull int.
sp.l: What a mockerie hath death made of thee? thou look'st sad.
In what place art thou? in you starrie gallerie,
Or in the cursed dungeon? No? not speake?
Pray, Sir, resolue mee, what religions best
For a man to die in? or is it in your knowledge
To answere mee how long I haue to liue?
That's the most necessarie question.
Not answere? Are you still like some great men
That onely walke like shadowes vp and downe,
And to no purpose: say:—
sp.stage: The Ghost throwes earth vpon him and shewes him the scull.
sp.l: What's that? O fatall! hee throwes earth vpon mee.
A dead mans scull beneath the rootes of flowers.
I pray speake Sir, our Italian Church-men
Make vs beleue, dead men hold conference
With their familiars, and many times
Will come to bed to them, and eat with them.
Hee's gone; and see, the scull and earth are vanisht.
This is beyond melancholie. I doe dare my fate
To doe its worst. Now to my sisters lodging,
And summe vp all these horrours; the disgrace
The Prince threw on mee; next the pitious sight
Of my dead brother; and my Mothers dotage;
And last this terrible vision. All these
Shall with Vittoria's bountie turne to good,
Or I will drowne this weapon in her blood.

sp.speaker: LOD.
sp.l: My Lord vpon my soule you shall no further:
You haue most ridiculously ingag'd your selfe
Too far allready. For my part, I haue payd
All my debts, so if I should chance to fall
My Creditours fall not with mee; and I vow
To quite all in this bold assemblie
To the meanest follower. My Lord leaue the Cittie,
Or Ile forsweare the murder.

sp.speaker: FRAN.
sp.l: Farewell Lodouico.
If thou do'st perish in this glorious act,
Ile reare vnto thy memorie that fame
Shall in the ashes keepe aliue thy name.

sp.speaker: HOR.
sp.l: There's some blacke deed on foot. Ile presently
Downe to the Citadell, and raise some force.
These strong Court factions that do brooke no checks,
In the cariere of't breake the Riders neckes.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: What are you at your prayers? Giue o're.
sp.stage: Enter Vittoria with a booke in her hand. Zanke, Flamineo, following them.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: How Ruffin?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I come to you 'bout worldly businesse:
Sit downe, sit downe: Nay stay blouze, you may heare it,
The dores are fast inough.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Ha, are you drunke?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Yes, yes, with wormewood water, you shall tast
Some of it presently.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: What intends the fury?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: You are my Lords Executrix, and I claime
Reward, for my long seruice.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: For your seruice

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Come therfore heere is pen and Inke, set downe
What you will giue me.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: There,

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Ha! haue you done already,
'Tis a most short conueyance.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I will read it.
I giue that portion to thee, and no other
Which Caine gron'd vnder hauing slaine his brother.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: A most courtly Pattent to beg by.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: You are a villaine.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Is't come to this? the say affrights cure agues:
Thou hast a Deuill in thee; I will try
If I can scarre him from thee: Nay sit still:
My Lord hath left me yet two case of Iewels
Shall make me scorne your bounty; you shall see them.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Sure hee's distracted.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: O he's desperate
sp.stage: He enter with two of pistols.
sp.l: For your owne safety giue him gentle language.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Looke, these are better far at a dead list,
Then all your iewell house.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: And yet mee thinkes,
These stones haue no faire lustre, they are ill set.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I'le turne the right side towards you: you shall see how the will sparkle.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Turne this horror from mee:
What do you want? what would you haue mee doe?
Is not all mine, yours? haue I any children?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Pray theee good woman doe not trouble mee
With this vaine wordly businesse; say your prayers,
I made a vow to my deceased Lord,
Neither your selfe, nor I should out-liue him,
The numbring of foure howers.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Did he enioyne it.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: He did, and 'twas a deadly iealousy,
Least any should enioy thee after him;
That vrg'd him vow me to it: For my death
I did propound it voluntarily, knowing
If hee could not be safe in his owne Court
Being a great Duke, what hope then for vs?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: This is your melancholy and dispaire.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Away,
Foole, thou art to thinke that Polititians
Do vse to kill the effects of iniuries
And let the cause liue: shall we groane in irons,
Or be a shamefull and a waighty burthen
To a publicke scaffold: This is my resolue
I would not liue at any mans entreaty
Nor dye at any's bidding.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Will you heare me?

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: My life hath done seruice to other men,
My death shall serue mine owne turne; make you ready

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Do you meane to die indeed.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: With as much pleasure
As e're my father gat me.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Are the dores lockt?

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Yes Madame.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Are you growne an Atheist? will you turne your body,
Which is the goodly pallace of the soule
To the soules slaughter house? ô the cursed Deuill
Which doth present vs with all other sinnes
Thrice candied ore; Despaire with gaule and stibium,
Yet we carouse it off; Cry out for helpe,
Makes vs forsake that which was made for Man,
The world, to sinke to that was made for deuils,
Eternall darkenesse.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I'le stop your
With Winter plums,

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: I prethee yet remember, (throate
Millions are now in graues, which at last day
Like Mandrakes shall rise shreeking.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Leaue your prating,
For these are but grammaticall laments,
Feminine arguments, and they moue me
As some in Pulpits moue their Auditory
More with their exclamation then sence
Of reason, or sound Doctrine.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Gentle Madam
Seeme to consent, onely perswade him teach
The way to death; let him dye first.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: 'Tis good, I apprehend it,
To kill one's selfe is meate that we must take
Like pils, not chew't, but quickly swallow it,
The smart a'th wound, or weakenesse of the hand
May else bring trebble torments.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: I haue held it
A wretched and most miserable life,
Which is not able to dye.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O but frailty!
Yet I am now resolu'd, farewell affliction;
Behold Brachiano, I that while you liu'd
Did make a flaming Altar of my heart
To sacrifice vnto you; Now am ready
To sacrifice heart and all. Fare-well Zanche.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: How Madam! Do you thinke that I'le out-liue you?
Especially when my best selfe Flamineo
Goes the same voiage.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O most loued Moore!

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Onely by all my loue let me entreat you;
Since it is most necessary none of vs
Do violence on our selues; let you or I
Be her sad taster, teach her how to dye.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Thou dost instruct me nobly, take these pistols,
Because my hand is stain'd with bloud already:
Two of these you shall leuell at my brest,
Th'other gainst your owne, and so we'le dye,
Most equally contented: But first sweare
Not to out-liue me.

sp.speaker: VIT. & MOO.
sp.l: Most religiously.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Then here's an end of me: fare-well day-light
And ô contemtible Physike! that dost take
So long a study, onely to preserue
So short a life, I take my leaue of thee.
These are two cupping-glasses, that shall draw
All my infected bloud out,
Are you ready?

sp.speaker: BOTH.
sp.l: Ready.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Whither shall I go now? O Lucian thy ridiculous Purgatory to finde Alexander the great cobling shooes, Pompey tagging points, and Iulius Caesar; making haire buttons, Haniball selling blacking, and Augustus crying garlike, Charlemaigne selling lists by the dozen, and King Pippin crying Apples in a cart drawn with one horse.
sp.l: Whether I resolue to Fire, Earth, water, Aire,
Or all the Elements by scruples; I know not
Nor greatly care,— Shoote, shoote,
Of all deaths the violent death is best,
For from our selues it steales our selues so fast
sp.stage: They shoot and run to him & tread vpon him.
sp.l: The paine once apprehended is quite past.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: What are you drop't.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: I am mixt with Earth already: As you are Noble Performe your vowes, and brauely follow mee.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Whither to hell,

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: To most assured damnation.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O thou most cursed deuill.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Thou art caught

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: In thine owne Engine, I tread the fire out
That would haue bene my ruine.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.p: Will you be periur'd? what a religious oath was Stix that the Gods neuer durst sweare by and violate? ô that wee had such an oath to minister, and to be so well kept in our Courts of Iustice.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: Thinke whither thou art going.

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: And remember
What villanies thou hast acted.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: This thy death,
Shall make me like a blazing ominous starre,
Looke vp and tremble.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O I am caught with a springe!

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: You see the Fox comes many times short ho me,
'Tis here prou'd true.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: Kild with a couple of braches.

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: No fitter offring for the infernall furies
Then one in whom they raign'd while hee was liuing.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O the waies darke and horrid! I cannot see,
Shall I haue no company?

sp.speaker: VIT.
sp.l: O yes thy sinnes,
Do runne before thee to fetch fire from hell,
To light thee thither.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O I smell soote, most sinking soote, the chimneis a fire,
My liuers purboil'd like scotch holly-bread;
There's a plumber, laying pipes in my guts, it scalds;
Wilt thou out-liue mee?

sp.speaker: ZAN.
sp.l: Yes, and driue a stake
Through thy body; for we'le giue it out,
Thou didst this violence vpon thy selfe.

sp.speaker: FLA.
sp.l: O cunning Deuils! now I haue tri'd your loue,
And doubled all your reaches. I am not wounded:
The pistols held no bullets: 'twas a plot
To proue your kindnesse to mee; and I liue
To punish your ingratitude, I knew
One time or other you would finde a way
